I really didn't want or need more to eat, but the dessert menu came out and I had a lovely chat about the gelatos with Kirk, my server. They had butter pecan gelato, and I just couldn't resist. Instead of the trio, he was happy to just bring me a scoop. All I can say is: Heaven. Evidently they have an adult milkshake with this butter pecan goodness and bourbon that is out of this world. Next time, for sure!!

I can be a bit critical and high maintenance, I admit it. So it was nice to be surprised by great service and a lovely meal! I  was so  impressed with the service, that I stopped at the host stand on my way out to have a bravo message passed along to the manager. 

And next time I'm in SF, I will definitely be back!
author: HAnne D.

description:
Watch your credit card card statement after eating here. I was double billed.

Wrt food the omelette was not really an omelette, more like a vegetable version of Japanese omu-rice.

Coffee service was attentive but was not hot.
author: Peter Y.

description: The concierge at our hotel suggested this place because we were starving and it's right across the street. I got the Grilled Chicken Panini and my husband got the Spaghetti & Meatballs. My sandwich was pretty killer and came with fries. The pasta was just okay. We had two drinks each and the bill was $57...a little pricey for lunch but sometimes you pay for convenience. Would eat there again if we were starving!
author: Lauren P.

description: Great location. They have happy hour on Sunday which was awesome. We ordered wine ($3) with calamari ($6) Caesar salad ($5) mussels and fries ($9) from the lesser priced bar menu. The wine selection was a little sparse but the price is right. The atmosphere in very calm and comfortable. I highly recommend this classy easy joint.
author: Jenny G.

description:
The highs = Great location, nice crowd, FANTASTIC happy hour, flexible kids menu.

The lows = About as loud as a Metallica concert during the aforementioned happy hour, sloooooooow service, so-so food.

We met a friend of ours that was in town with her 5 year old daughter there on a crowded Friday night, had a fairly small-ish table in the middle of the place & I think I caught every other word in our conversation.  The place just amplifies the ambient noise by at least 9-12dB & it just resonates as one big wash of white noise.   So anyway, I had the veggie lasagna, decent.  Tried some of the Frutti Mare`, kinda salty/fishy & the report on the Bolengasse was the high point.

The meat dishes looked & smelled amazing, maybe should have gone that route but...
author: Bill T.

description: Soooo overpriced! The food wasn't bad at all; it was actually pretty good, although nothing to make me urge you to get. However we split an appetizer of bruschetta and we each got a simple pasta dish, and, with tip, it was $40 a person. Too expensive for the simple spaghetti and meatballs! The meatballs are good however! Did I mention we all drank water? No alcohol on that bill!
author: Katie P.

description:
I went to Puccini & Pinetti last weekend. The place is at good location and aesthetics are nice. 
Food was "OK" nothing mind blowing and I wont exactly call it fine dinning. Pasta I ordered failed to bring all the flavors together and not everything that was mentioned on menu was there. Too much tomato sauce and that was all I could taste and smell.  
Our waiter was good and patient as one of my friend took an hour to join us. Though the manager of the restaurant was not at all nice to us. She was staring at our table all the time like a dead goat  which was quite uncomfortable and bit disgusting. 
So I give: 
 *** for the aesthetics
 ** for food
 * for customer service
Overall ** .
author: Pardeep S.

description:
Puccini & Pinetti is a great alternative to the many restaurants located in downtown especially away from the long wait at Cheesecake Factory. I love the location especially since it's just around the corner to Urban Outfitters. 

Yesterday was my first time at Puccini & Pinetti and I was skeptical of the touristy location, but ended really enjoying my meal. The service was unusually good! From the order, to the water, to the checking back, to the food, to the good byes, they didn't miss a beat. 

Puccini & Pinetti might not be the BEST Italian restaurant but it's definitely good. I made a last minute reservation on opentable.com (love the website) for a table at 730pm. I arrived 30 minutes early but the restaurant was kind of busy so the Hostess suggested my companion and me to come back in 20 minutes, so we end up walking around Urban and walked back to Puccini. Right when we walked in, the Hostess seated us quickly. 

I love the Focaccia bread they serve w/olive oil before your meal. I recommend the Bruschetta, Marisa Chicken & Lamb Chops (cooked in medium rare please). Many people ordered the spaghetti with meatballs, it looks good but I just don't like eating a lot of carbs for dinner. Prices can range from $11-25.00 a plate, the portions are just right but if you feel your food wont fill you up, you can always ask your waiter for more bread. Our food came pretty fast. One thing I enjoy most about Puccini is their open kitchen, so you don't have to worry about the chefs spitting in your food if you accidentally or purposely pissed them off. 

The wait staff was very professional, friendly and tentative. I give my waitress 5 stars just because she kept coming back with our refills and I drank at least 5 cups of water. I wonder why the glasses are so small when they could just serve us bigger glasses so the waitress doesn't have to keep refilling. 

Tip: Always try to find FREE street parking after 6pm. All the yellow zones are for free, there are always empty spots near Nann and Curry or if you are lucky you can always find a spot along the street across from H&M. Never paid for parking on a weekday!

hmmm...and for desert -- Coldstones is right next door! :)
author: Carol Y.

description: Gorgeous dim lighting, great ambience, delicious food! Went mainly for the awesome happy hour deal ( and to convince my boyfriend that there is, in fact, good Italian to be found in the TL). Sat at a table, then realized the bar area has the full menu but much cheaper drinks. We moved, and they were very nice about it. Had the Caesar, calamari, and rigatoni. ALL sooooo awesome! We'll be back!
author: Rosalee S.

description: Eh- it was just OK. Service was quite good, but the food was mediocre at best. Don't expect great food though.
author: Katie E.

description: The service was outstanding - they were able to accommodate a last-minute reservation for five and all of the staff were super attentive and friendly. Food tasted great and portions were large. I went for a casual dinner with colleagues and will definitely return on my next visit.
author: Victoria B.

description:
I came here for happy hour appetizers - $3 each! Gotta love that! The food, however, took forever to come. FOREVER! But for $3 per dish, I shouldn't complain.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
It's Italian goodness, polite service, clean interior and filling excellent food. I've been here twice, and would come back for more.


That's when you know you've got it bad in the good way.
author: Jessica R.

description:
One of the best happy hours I have ever been to! Sundays are all day happy hour in the bar area and even if its not happy hour, their bar menu has great items for around $5. During happy hour, they had a red or white wine for $3 a glass. I tired both and they were great; the red wasn't too fruity and the white wasn't too oaky or buttery. 

My friend and I each had half a dozen oysters for $1 an oyster. They were creamy and fresh. We also had the pasta nachos, which had crispy wontons, instead of chips and had a good helping of fennel sausage and cheese. We also had the fig pizza. There were large fresh figs, crispy crust, goat cheese and arugula. Amazing pizza. This place is located close to Union Square, so its great for lunch on a busy shopping day.
author: Brigid T.

description:
I ate a delicious Chicken Marsala. The waiter was good although he had to check if he could provide separate checks (company expenses).  

The table wasn't ready for about 15 mins with the reservation.

This was my third time at the restaurant and I would come again.
author: Lyndsey F.

description: Very spendy. Our 15 year old loved the pasta dish she had. The spaghetti and meatballs were ok. I had the olives and the mussels from the app menu and both were just ok. Our waiter was outstanding and everything was super fast. We ate very late so there were menu items that we would have ordered if it would have been regular dinner time. The menu is comprehensive. We had over an hour wait for a table on a Sunday.
author: A L.

description:
I came to Puccini and Pinetti for lunch the other day. The very friendly server suggested trying the sausage pizza with arugula, pomodoro and grilled sweet onions. Sounded good at the time. I think I might've come at the wrong time or wrong day but the pizza turned out to be very oily and almost gloppy. I lifted a slice to take a bite and the melted cheese and pomodoro sauce drooped off the crust like a landslide in slow motion. I had no choice but to eat with a fork and knife instead.

I was starving and so I continued to eat as much of it as possible. When I went back to work, I noticed that I felt gloppy inside as well. I moved slower than the landslide on my pizza. But despite the bad pizza day, I've had better meals there in the past and so I will definitely come back and just try something else. The friendly staff made up for the mediocre meal and the restaurant maintains a clean and enjoyable atmosphere. So three stars for that!
author: Anne E.

description: We've eaten here several times already and I would definitely recommend this place to all the bay area yelpers out there. Okay. I know what you're going to ask next... Why oh Why?  My answer is simple. They serve honest, straightforward  Italian food.
author: Kit P.

description: cute little place. mature crowd, it was nice to have a quite place to have a cup of coffee and desert.  the server seemed stressed out but overall was polite.  the desert was great.
author: Carla P.

description:
This is the place to go for happy hour in SF.  Great price for the bubbly and wine, food is good too. Get there early to grab a seat, bar is best to seat for faster service.

Been there a few times, would go back again and again!
author: Ken E.

description:
I'll be coming back to this place.  Service was good. Frutti di Mare was spectacular and the Pumpkin Cheesecake was out of this world.
Seemed like a local crowd, which is refreshing since it sits right in the middle of Tourist Central (not as bad as Fishermans' wharf, but close).
author: Pedro D.

description:
Two words everyone: PASTA...NACHOS!

Yep...that is all. LOL j/k

Well not really. Everytime I'm at work or just want to hang out and kick it with some folks (that is before my figure contest prep), I'd just settle into this gem of SF with their happy hour menu you can't beat. I've turned my co workers and friends on to this place simply because of their delicious happy hour options (pasta nachos in particular). 
The entire staff are hard at work when its busy so just give them a moment, they'll take care of you. Jessica, the restaurant's manager is someone you can really rely on for great service. Not only is she dead-on about making sure you're taken care of, but a very, very sweet lady. :) You'll always see the blonde petite woman powering her way through the happy hour lunch/dinner crowd keeping a hawk-eye on anything that seems to be out of place. She's there to help with orders, seating, or just to lend an ear. :) Fabulous!!
So I'm definitely a fan for life! It does tend to get extremely busy there during happy hour so if you're not lucky to get there in time for a seat, be prepared to wait! Its definitely worth it in my opinion.

Oh, did I already mention the Pasta Nachos....?
author: Meka H.

description: Stay away from the oysters! They were pretty much inedible. The crab cakes were ok though and the service was good.
author: Melanie N.

description: Terrible service, waited for over an hour for my water to get refilled.   Bread and oil is great.  food is good.  Overall not impressed
author: Scott S.

description: I had the warm spinach salad and chicken Marsala and it was delicious!! They had to take away my plate before I embarrassed myself. I also had the affigato for dessert and it was equally delish. They have a very nice selection of gluten free options for those who are looking for that which was important to my dinner companion. She had the salmon and I think she enjoyed it. I'm coming back for the chicken Marsala for sure!!
author: Al C.

description: We made a reservation for 8 at noon.  We were seated promptly.  Because we were going to the Golden Gate Theatre, we were given a complimentary brushetta appetizer, the most delicious I have even had.  The tomatoes were so red and full of flavor. The beet salad and vegetable salad were great.  ÷Everyone loved their food in our party.  The servoce was geat. We loved our lunch at this place and will come back
author: Mary K.

description: Good food, super nice server fair price for the area. We ate in the bar area so we didn't have to wait so it was a bit loud. I would recommend and definitely go back when in town again.
author: Rob V.

description: Took some family from out of town here and was so disappointed. Have been here a few times in the past and always had a good experience.  Not this time.  Hostess was incredibly rude to my family, the food was just okay, not worth the price. The bread they served us after finally being sat at our table was stale and cold but the dip that came with it was awesome. The only good part of this let down was the servers, they're awesome, both in the bar area and in the restaurant.  Honestly if I could've come up with another option for our large party I would've just left.
author: Kathi K.

description: Love the location, love the atmosphere, love the champagne, love the cute waiters.  If you like your sparkling wines on the sweeter side, the bottle they serve at happy hour is a sure thing.
author: Mike B.

description: Burger was amazing, even though this was an Italian place. But be sure to try the meatballs - super tender, just the right amount of cheese and spices.
author: Mark A.

description:
I cannot believe I ordered spaghetti and meatballs in an Italian restaurant!!!

I broke one of my cardinal rules...never order something I could make better at home (I must make amends to all my Italian ancestors).

Ok, so I was only half "in the mood" for Italian food when I went here.  A buddy of mine and I were searching desperately downtown for a place to grab dinner after a long day's work when we happened upon P & P.

The place is nicely decorated and was full of people and pretty lively (for what, I recall was a Sunday night).

I had a nice chianti with my *gasp* spaghetti (yes, it's like ordering fried rice in a Chinese restaurant) and the bread was quite tasty so that made up for my order.

The spaghetti was actually pretty salty (specifically it was the meatballs).  I usually have a huge salt craving and will add it to almost all my foods...but in this case the meatballs seemed to be saltier than the SF bay!  It was almost like salt was used in place of the usual bread crumbs or garlic....ack!

I will not be too harsh since the service was good and I'd have to give it another try to confirm (could be a fluke).  I should have requested a different meat so it's partially my fault.

My buddy had what could have been mistaken for "cioppino" but was actually "frutti di mare".  Basically the pasta and seafood dish was extremely soupy which to me is a huge turn off because if I wanted soup and noodles I'd go eat some ramen or won ton soup.  I'm wondering if that's they're "style" or if they just didn't drain the seafood after boiling it....it's supposed to be saucy enough to dip your bread but it just looked like soup.

Worth a try if you're ever downtown SF.



(on a side note...the atmosphere was almost completely ruined by some cackling chick/yeti/hyena-lady who was WAYYY too amused by her two friends and voice seemed like it was about to make the paint fall off the ceiling into my food - if I ever get that loud after some wine...just throw me under a cable car please!)
author: Richard C.

description: Everything about this place was terrible. You would find more authentic and tasty food at Olive Garden (seriously!).  The noise level was high.  The wait staff- most importantly- was so pushy that we had barely planted ourselves at our table before she was essentially telling us what to order. When we asked for a moment to catch our breath and look at the menu, she grudgingly gave us 2 full minutes before returning to the table and aggressively urging us once again to order a large round of hors d'oevres. The story goes on. In short, our waitress was pushy, impatient, and then neglectful -- completely unsatisfactory.  The food was less than mediocre.  The prices were inflated.  And the ambiance had all the charm of a Bennigans.  Stay away.  You can do much better elsewhere.
author: A Z.

description: The mussels and rigatoni are great! Excellent service and good food!
author: Ariela O.

description: Pasta in bolognese sauce with meatballs and the bruschetta app were super. Don't order a dirty martini they are lame!
author: Allyson M.

description:
While I give this place three stars for normal meals (lunch and dinner), I would have to give it four stars for happy hour. Puccini has great happy hour specials (4-6 PM on weekdays): $3 beers and wines, and $3 to $4 appetizers with such generous portions that you might as well call it a light dinner.

Appetizers I would recommend: 
- Pasta nachos with asiago cream sauce, tomatoes, basil, kalamata olives, parmesan, and mozzarella ($3)
- Cripsy calamari with zucchini, fennel, onion, lemon, and sweet tomato aioli ($3)
- Flatbread pizza ($4)

My favorite by far would be the pasta nachos, which have just the right amount of cream sauce and mozzarella with a generous amount of toppings. Definitely goes well with any beer (and Puccini happens to have Stella Artois, another favorite of mine).

So if you're ever in the area and need a midday snack, check this place out!

(See acompanying photos!)
author: Lisa M.

description:
A rather uninspired Italian joint across from the Parc 55 hotel. Too pricey for average food and mediocre service. 

Our group of eight came in here for a business lunch. We were probably the only customers in here besides a couple two-top tables. It was a little sad inside for being the downtown lunch rush.

The food came out fairly quickly, but only 3 plates. Then several minutes later, another plate. 5 minutes later, another plate. Then 10 minutes or so later 2 more. Finally, the last plate came. Didn't really make sense since most of the dishes were salads. My dish was fine--I ordered a roasted veggie panini ($12) and finished it since I was really hungry. The other dishes looked ok, but nothing special or particularly memorable. 

I wouldn't see another reason to come here unless you're staying at the Parc 55 Hotel and everything else (including the hotel's own restaurant) is closed. Or maybe for their $3 champagne at happy hour, but only if you're in the neighborhood. Otherwise, it deserves a meh.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Great food, at okay prices. Cannot complain. Thankfully most of the staff we were serviced by were pleasant. The hostess (Ellen?) was very nice and polite and made accomodations to sit us at the table we wanted near the window. 

Ordered the Bruschetta appetizer and that was very tasty.

For the entree I ordered the Saltimbocca(sp?) which is the veal wrapped in prosciutto, and it was flat out awesome.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Alex G.

description:
I take my sister to this place every time she comes to visit me.  It was originally a random find but I'm so glad we stumbled upon it!!  We usually come here for Happy Hour and order various appetizers to save room for the real reason we come: the Valrhona Truffle Cake.  This is seriously the best cake I have ever had and I usually hate cake.  I seriously recommend giving this place a try solely for the cake.  

The Bruschetta and crab cakes are really good too.  I never noticed any hard bits in the bruschetta that one of the other reviewers mentioned.
author: Zara C.

description: Nice atmosphere but extremely slow service. We had breakfast. All of the eggs were served great. Lousy potatoes and on the cold side. Expensive for breakfast.
author: Patti A.

description:
The happy hour at this place can't be beat.  It lasts for a ludicrously long time and offers very cheap (especially for Union Square) drink deals for a good selection of beers and appetizers.  

Things to keep in mind:  Happy Hour only works if you're in the designated "Bar Area," and if you start ordering wine and beer in the restaurant area your bill will rack up while you sit blissfully unaware.

Fortunately, the "bar area" takes up half the place, has the best views of the nightlife outside, is always nice and quiet, and the wait staff is very good at taking care of you.  They have a bunch of tables to sit at, so you don't have to sit at the actual bar if you don't want to.

Also, you can order dinner from the bar area, so there's no real reason to even sit anywhere else.  And the food is great as well, but it is reflected in the price.  

A great place that almost seems too good to be true.
author: Nick F.

description:
I've eaten here in the bar, and enjoyed it immensely.  I decided to try the main restaurant.  I was by myself, and was told it would be a 15 to 20 minute wait for a table, which was OK.  Then I'm told they have a table for me right now...

In the back, in an empty room, except for two other people that were getting ready to leave.  I'm brought water and bread, and I wait.  And wait.  And wait.  And wait.  And wait.  Get the picture?  I finally just walked out, never seeing my server. 

I guess they don't like solo diners?  Too bad, I judge a restaurant on how well they treat solos.  P & P has failed.
author: J L.

description:
I genuinely liked this place, and I'm shocked because my friends and I came across it out of hunger desperation. And believe me, you rarely end up at a good restaurant when you are starving and reckless. 

Anyways, started out with a drink (of course), and was pleasantly surprised to see a caipirinha on the drink menu. Those are my FAVORITE, and have only once actually seen them listed before. So yay me!

After being seated we were brought out some amazing focaccia bread and olive oil dipping sauce. I'm not exactly sure what was in the dip, but it was very good.

I ordered the short ribs, which came with carrots and pesto mashed potatoes. This place would have gotten a 5th star if the short ribs hadn't been in much need of salt. But other than that, I was very satisfied.

Give this place a try if you are looking for a restaurant after a long day of shopping and walking around SF, you will not be disappointed.
author: Jaime A.

description:
"72"  You have to like the number "72" if you want to eat here.  Why?  Because that is how long we had to wait for our food to land on our table.  That is ONE hour, TWELVE minutes waiting at our table for food to arrive.   Do you know how long that is?    It's so long, that most of us had to get up and walk around because our bodies started aching from sitting in the chair for so long... 

The restaurant was only 80% full, the waiter explained that the Chef was having an "off" day.    Really?   We think the server AND the kitchen needed help.   The waiter, very kind, but very inefficient.   Did not have any clue on when to take our orders, when to clean the plates, when to take coffee/dessert orders.    There seemed to be a 20 minute gap between servings; so that made the dinner drag out even longer.

We must have finished our entrees' for at least 15 minutes before he came and remembered to request coffee and dessert from us.   We were SO tired from the meal, all of us passed.    We had 11 at our table, ALSO one meal was forgotten; and he had to wait 19 minutes for his meal to arrive.    Everyone else almost finished their dinner by the time the last meal hit the table.    Our waiter nor the manager bothered to come to our table to offer any type of apologies for the long wait.  I am sure food tickets are time stamped; you would know if the kitchen is behind.  The WAITERS have to know the delays; they should be the ones most apologetic.   How many times you ask did OUR waiter offer an apology?   ZERO.    

Now the food - I ate here maybe 5 years ago; thought the restaurant was nice.   However tonite was bad, really bad food:   

SPINACH SALAD - too much balsamic, made the whole plate too tart to eat (mouth was stinging).

FRUTTI di Mare (Seafood pasta) - recommended by the Waiter as his "favorite".   Should have been called "Flavor-less di Mare".   This special had no taste at all; the chef CLEARLY forgot to taste the food before serving.   It was missing "something"....I am thinking a little SALT or some more TOMATOES might have helped.   

CAESAR salad - ahhh, a simple dish you think?   Only if you like the Garlic ratio 100 to 1.    You had to scrape the garlic off the leaves; clumps, and clumps.

FRIED Calamari - please try to serve the dish HOT, it was lukewarm by the time it arrived our table.
author: Edward H.

description:
Went there for dinner. The staff was extremely friendly, and they got us seated pretty quickly despite the restaurant being full.

We had a half-bottle of Syrah, as suggested by the waitress, and despite its high price we enjoyed it very much. Started with some bruschetta, which was just so-so, but the goat cheese accentuated it.

I ordered the Pan-seared sea scallops, which were fantastic. The prosciutto and asparagus risotto that comes with it was so delicious that I couldn't stop eating it. My boyfriend had the cannelloni. It was very rich in flavour and he enjoyed it very much too.

We ordered tiramisu as dessert. It was decent, but there were no surprises there.

I will definitely stop by again, especially for the bread and olive oil with sun dried tomatoes and capers which they served right after the drinks were served. Just can't stop eating those!
author: Alice C.

description: I had the spare ribs and it was something right out of an old folks home. My husband  had the bucatini arrabiata which was Not arrabiata (spicy). The service was horrible. The waiter ignored us most of the night and we had to wait forever to try and catch his attention for the check. Yuck.
author: Brandina D.

description: Went to happy hour here for the first time. The bar menu appetizers are ok....not great by any stretch, but a good value during happy hour. Go early or you will not get a seat in the bar area....3:30 at the latest....3:00 would be better. The service is really pretty bad so you better plan on ordering just once.
author: John M.

description:
Hmm... we were there for happy hour (even if we were a bigger group of people with reservations), and were told that we can't order with the happy hour prices. Seriously - wouldn't you want our huge group ordering tons of food, including dinner..?

Good thing for them, the food was good. I'm not raving about the food and would have chosen dim sum for the better experience, variety and fun. The lasagna with pesto and marinara looked delicious. Perhaps I should've had what my friend ordered, not my tiny little salmon.
author: Christine M.

description: Great Caprese salad... really fresh and tasty. My son had the pizza and it was excellent too. I would definitely like to go back for dinner to get the whole dining experience, but I really enjoyed the lunch. Friendly, attentive staff and cute space.
author: Susan G.

description: This place is a pit. Service is horrible and the Management are complete snobs. Food was gross, better Italian food from Costco.  The Location has more drugs addicts and bums that a rehab center. There is more than a hundred other Italian restaurants to choose from,  please do yourself a favor and eat somewhere else.
author: Scott T.

description:
Very friendly and attentive staff. One of the chefs actually came out to say hi and recommended his favorite dish to us. We didn't end up ordering that one; perhaps we should have?!

I had the herbed duck bolognese - not bad, but unfortunately not too memorable either.. We also tried their Warm Spinach Salad - also not bad. I didn't like the bread they served at the beginning - a bit tough for me. 

The atmosphere is classy and can be romantic, depending on where you get seated cos the dinning area is only separated with the bar area by a low divider.. Sitting near the bar can be quite loud. There are definitely more older folks (late 30s -40s+) on the dining side... All in all, an okay dining experience.

On an off topic note, make sure you check out the bathrooms, haha. The bathrooms are not inside the restaurant, but inside the hotel next door and are VERY nice. LOL.
author: HP L.

description:
This restaurant has a warm and cosy semi-formal atmosphere and great food. I've only eaten in the bar and they have cheap smaller dishes that you can share like tapas or eat for yourself. They're usually enough if you're not overly hungry. The staff is really nice and you always feel welcomed here. The drinks are quite expensive but they have happy hour so it's a great spot to stop by after work.  
I love their pasta nachos, they are delicious!
author: Anna H.

description:
My friend and I came in for lunch after shopping at Union Square. We ordered drinks and I was recommended the mojito by the bartender so I got it. It was good but not the best I'd ever had.

We decided to order some small plates and got the olives, fried ravioli, cheese plate, and bruschetta. It was all very delicious and plenty for two people. I didn't like that all of the olives were pitted but I guess that makes it more authentic. 

It was a nice place to go for lunch and a cocktail.
author: A K.

description:
Very good service. We went for lunch at 1:30PM, so it wasn't that busy. I booked a reservation using Open Table and we got a free appetizer, bread with cream cheese and sauteed tomatoes. I had the spaghetti and meatballs ($20). There was a lot of meat. I enjoyed it. The meatballs felt like they were pre-made though. I also got to try the steak panini. It was pretty good as well ($12). For an appetizer, we also had the fritto misto, which is basically calamari. It was tasty as well. There were crispy pieces, but there were some that were a bit chewy. 

This restaurant also participates in the Passport Unlimited program.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Really good service and good food. We made a dinner of appetisers and it was more than enough for two people.  I highly recommend the warm spinach salad...Perfectly carmelized onions with mushrooms and a baslamic vinegrette.
author: Lis C.

description:
Stayed at the Parc 55 Wyndham directly across the street and stumbled upon this restaurant right as they were closing. They had a sign on their windows advertising Happy Hour $3 beer and wine, and it's false advertising! They have a special menu for their happy hour drinks which I'm not mad about, but just don't advertise falsely outside to lure people in. We sit down at the bar around 9:50 and the host recommends us to order before last call. The male bartender was super nice and friendly, offering different recommendations about beer and cocktails. Appreciated the service and strong drinks! The place was still packed even though it was 10PM on a Sunday! 

So we're drinking, enjoying a nice night in SF being from out of town, and a guy sits down a few seats away at 10:10pm and the nice bartender happily served him anyway. We hear him order a margherita pizza and a house cabernet off their happy hour menu. The nice bartender who was serving him was super accommodating, got him the cab right away but came back a few minutes later and regretfully but kindly informed him that the kitchen had already closed. The man literally yelled and cussed aloud "That's f$^%ing bulls&*%!!", and the bartender kept his cool and still felt bad! He offered the man the Cab on the house and again reiterated his apologies. My girlfriend and I felt bad for the nice bartenders, and were angered at the insanely rude customer. It's not their fault! They served him anyway! The guy was rude, just rude. Needless to say, we finished our drinks quickly and left right away..
author: Adam Z.

description:
This place used to have a really nice happy hour. Now they have taken a favorite dish (fried ravioli, umm) OFF the menu (the nachos need to be removed), the space sometimes is not enough and last night a server was both unpleasant and unprofessional without excuse. Not once, but twice.

My food came out undercooked. After offering to refire (ugh) my food, he (the manager) comes back with a new plate minus the other half to go with the recooked food.

Poor management action requires me to take this place off my dining list.

In this world, credibility, is everything.
author: L W.

description:
Visited this establishment on a Wednesday evening with some business associates of my spouse.  This is the only reason why I remained poised during my dinner experience. 
The waitstaff was friendly but unattentive and incompetent. The reservations specifically noted that 2 very young children would be on the party, yet we were seated at a table close to the hustle and bustle of the kitchen.  On to the food...marginal at best. I ordered the chicken Marsala and my spouse ordered the Fruiti de Mare.  My dish was doused with an overwhelming amount of very salty Marsala sauce. Perhaps the sauce was used to mask the artificial texture of the chicken and take your attention away from the overcooked spinach.  My husband's dish looked soupy and the pasta was clumpy.  He picked at his food and merely moved it around on his plate. The children's order was only partially fulfilled.  We had to remind our server multiple times for a simple glass of milk so the mother could refill their sippy cups. The children's food, when it finally arrived, was too hot for adults to eat, yet alone children.  The server then proceeded to place the steaming plates in front of the youngest child, who immediately recoiled from the visible steam.  Finally, onto dessert...I ordered gelato. Or should I say ice cream from the supermarket presented in a fancy bowl with a high mark-up.  Overall one of the most disappointing dining experiences ever. Will not even drink the water in the middle of a heat wave if it comes from this restaurant.
author: Chanel N.

description: Our hotel bartender suggested this place.  The restaurant is fairly large and has a quaint bar area.  We ordered short ribs and spaghetti with meatballs.  The short ribs were very tender and juicy, and rested on a pile of pesto mashed potatoes and veggies. The spaghetti was a typical Italian dish -- nice, thick marinara sauce and several large, juicy meatballs.  The red wine was forgettable.
author: Carol S.

description:
Went out to dinner on a Saturday night (make sure you have reservations) and had great service and great food.  Everyone at our table was a member of the clean plate club.

The one downfall was the noise - it was hard to carry on a good conversation.
author: Anna H.

description:
The Burrata was amazing. I could eat that all day.
The papardelle with chicken was very good. The pasta was very delicate and the flavors were all good. I did notice that it had kind of a flour-y taste, which was a bit strange. The chicken was a little dry, but really it was a good pasta dish, nice and creamy. The people dining with me had the Rigatoni Bolognese, which was really good and a bit lighter. Service was fine, we were there for lunch on a Saturday and it wasn't crowded. We had two glasses of Prosecco, the Burrata appetizer and the two pastas and the bill came to $80, so a bit expensive, but tasty. Serving sizes of the pasta were quite large, definitely enough to take home and eat for another meal.
author: Kathy M.

description:
Disclosure: I have only been here for happy hour, so I really can't say anything about their actual dining room.

Their Happy Hour, however, is AWESOME! They have very cheap, small plates which are insanely tasty. My favorite dishes are, without a doubt, the fried calamari and the goat cheese fondue. So tasty, so cheap, and so fun to eat!

They have great happy hour deals on drinks as well- some legit beers on tap, cheap sparkling wine, mojitos, and red & white wines. You really can't go wrong.

The waiters have always been extremely friendly and attentive, and the location is insanely central, making it one of my frequent happy hour stops.

HAPPY HOUR FOR ALL!
author: Felicity M.

description:
Good value on happy hour for popular downtown spot right off BART

Not a gourmet meal but an urban bistro that gets you fed with decent portions.
author: Bill C.

description: Not really a family place, a bit pricy--highlight was bruschetta with goat cheese, Perroni on tap.
author: Robby W.

description: Everything was very good. Comfortable if a bit loud. Salads were flavorful. Terrific tapenade comes with good bread. The lemon risotto was phenomenal. Nice selection of wines by glass and beers on tap.
author: Scott G.

description:
I've been here for lunch and the happy hour.  Prices for the happy hour are good.  Happy hour times vary depending on the day, Monday and Tuesday being until 3 pm -10 pm and  3 pm -6 pm the rest of the week.  You can't beat a $3 glass of wine that's been generously poured.  The bar food ranges from good to meh and is also reasonably priced, starting at $3 for olives.

It' gets pretty loud and crowded as the happy hour progresses and becomes standing room only.  

If possible, get there early and you'll have a better time.
author: Scott S.

description:
I enjoy going here for happy hour.  It's easy to get to (just up the street from Powell BART) and usually fairly easy to find a table in the bar area.  The service is great, even when the place is packed.  I go with friends who want to enjoy some drinks and split a few appetizers.  That's the best way to sample their food. 

I highly recommend:
- Calamari: crispy and not too greasy with a tasty aioli
- Bruschetta: it has goat cheese in it! 
- Breaded ravioli: everything is more delicious breaded and fried, right? 

They have great drink prices during happy hour.  $3 champagne, wine, and select beers. $4 well drinks.  I think that's quite a deal, especially for a more tourist-y area of the city.
author: Emily J.

description: Great meal and atmosphere. The staff was very accommodating from the hostess to Ian the waiter.  We will be back!
author: Ron O.

description: Their red ale duchesse tastes like a wine mixed with beer. Kinda of Belgium style. Kevin the waiter was awesome, five star for him. Frito Miston is a great starter and not too much, right to the point for two people. Average risotto, nothing really special. But in overall is great, great people, great service, awesome environment! And dont forget to order the freaking truffle cake... Seriously, u have too... Prego!
author: Sudario A.

description: Had dinner there last night with some business colleagues. Overall the food was very good (had pasta penne special).  Appetizers, wine, and service were good as well. Overall a nice restaurant but the noise was deafening which is why only 3 stars. And we were all the way in the back corner.
author: Scott F.

description:
Argh! What a tourist sink-hole of fake San Francisco culture. Slow, indifferent bar staff, ridiculously overpriced drinks, unimaginative from-freezer-to-deep-fryer-like-a-Safeway-deli appetizers, and decor and ambiance that is reminiscent of Buca di Beppo with the edge taken off. 

You want Italian? Get your sorry ass out of Union Square and go to North Beach, for God's sake!
author: Elina R.

description: Enjoyed a top notch dinner here; although they close at 10 we arrived at 9:45 staff did not rush us, tended to our table often. Highlights were the tapenade spread and margherita pizza appetizer.Thin crispy crust with perfect amount of sauce and cheese. Seafood mare was fresh and good, the meatballs in bolognese sauce was extra meaty but not dense.
author: Bernard S.

description: Overpriced for sure. Kids pasta meals are $10.00 for a handful of pasta. Food was mediocre.
author: Rachel A.

description: Love this place! The happy hour is fantastic--reduced prices on both drinks and delicious bar food. I've already been twice in the last month and will keep going back.
author: Sarah R.

description:
I wrote this on their FB wall and I just want to share this here on YELP not to put down the restaurant but only to air my complaint to a particular waiter.

You have a rude waiter last night. I didn't bother to get his name because I'm really pissed. He's the weird, dinner waiter/server, tall, skinny guy, with eye glasses. I cannot help myself but to think that it's so effing racist of him. I'm Filipino, I was with my Bolivian co-worker friend and his Mexican girl friend. We went to your place to wait for my "Mexican" friend to have sushi dinner somewhere. When my friend arrived, he decided that he would just have dinner there because he's really hungry. He asked for the bar list and dinner menu. "That" waiter came and asked for our orders. (We've been drinking Peroni, which is on their happy hour list.) My Bolivian friend ordered calamari, garlic fries, nachos, and the meatballs which are all part of the happy hour menu. My Mexican friend (who's really fancy), ordered  white wine and a chicken burger, both are not part of the happy hour menu. He took our order and left. My fancy Mexican friend went to the restroom. "That" waiter came back and said, "the wine (he mentioned the name that I cannot remember) is not part of the happy hour, and the burger too", I said "Okay". He said "I just want to make sure." One time is okay, but really? He asked again my  fancy Mexican friend when he came back from the restroom saying, "Excuse me, I just want to tell you that the wine you have ordered is $9. Fancy Mexican said, "Yes I know". He could just have left and get the effing wine, but no, he said, "Well, I was just asking because, I mean $9, and happy hour wine is $4, you know you can get 2 glasses..." I said, "you've asked me already", he said, "oh I just want to make sure because sometimes a lot of people would be (making a face and irritating voice) oh, we didn't know it's not on happy hour, blah, blah, blah..." REALLY?!?!?! ARE YOU EFFING KIDDING ME?!?!? Is that the right way to talk to your customers??? I cannot help myself but  think that because we are "immigrants" and he would talk to us like that? FUCK THAT!!!
author: Jake D.

description:
Took my past girlfriend, when we were still together, there on a random sf outing.  We ordered the lunch special for two.
It was an amazing gourmet lunch.

P.S. the sorbet there is fantastic, except the grapefruit, which tended to be a bit bitter.
author: Jay P.

description: Wonderful dining experience for entire family. Our family, hosted a small dinner party here with help of event coordinator, Nicole. Dinner and appetizers were delicious, thank you to hostess Adrianne! I would definitely recommend this restaurant to friends in the city!
author: Mermaid A.

description: The food is good but nothing special.  It's your run of the mill Italian restaurant. Service was good though.
author: Brooke H.

description: I like it!  A bit loud but that adds to the atmosphere.  They have a nice, varied menu and good cocktails!
author: Jan C.

description:
All I can say is Happy Hour = I'm there. 

Um, who has happy hour on Sunday? P&P, that's who. And their happy hour prices are amaze-balls -- $3 Champagne, and no appetizers over $15. My group (read 3 carb-craving women) went there on a Sunday and ordered the fries, calamari, bruchetta, margherita pizza, fried mozzarella, and ravioli. There might have been double orders on a one or two of these menu items, but my lips are sealed.

Needless to say, we left sufficiently stuffed. Sometimes I'm a skeptic about restaurants around Union Square, but P&P put my (dining) fears to rest. The service was great as well -- even though they were quite packed.

Seriously folks, these prices are ridic. I hope I don't regret letting y'all in on my secret!
author: Ashley H.

description: Puccini & Pinetti is simply amazing.  I've been twice, on my two most recent trips to SF, and will continue to stop in anytime I'm in the bay area.  The staff is friendly, the food is deliscious (and I'm Italian, so I hold these places to my grandmothers cooking standards)...recommend the Short Ribs braised in red wine with the amazing Pesto Mashed Potatoes...the Rigatoni with Fennel Sausage is to die for, and the Alfredo is as good as I've had.  Make sure you order the Truffle cake for desert.  I'm not a big sweets fan, or chocalate, and I can't get enough of this thing.
author: Jason G.

description: great place for happy hour. 3$ wine that was good and extremely good apps that are all 3 and 4 bucks. incredible deal and food was very good. The brunch is not a good idea, $35.00 for steaks and eggs, i think not.
author: Greg T.

description:
For the first time in a very long time, I was not the oldest person at the bar.  Extra star.  Or perhaps not.
On my way to bart, he says "one more before you go" Yeah, ok, and we jump into the next place we come across. Crowded tables, crowded bar. Really crowded.  But as I looked about and fought my way to the bar, I noticed that most were older couples here for a lively dinner/drink session.  Don't get me wrong, it was very lively.
One woman sitting at the bar actually shared a bite of her pizza with me after she scolded us for allegedly jumping our drink order ahead hers.  The pizza was awesome. 
Decent drinks.  I assume most were there for dinner, unlike me.  I should go back and try dinner, really.  They must be doing something right, judging by the crowd.
author: Meg W.

description:
Horrible value.  

I was there for simple lunch: side ceasar, lasagna bolognese, tiramisu, a saphire and tonic.  $75!  The meal was ok, but doesn't compare to a $25 meal of the same items in Little Italy.  Actually, I've had better lasagna out of Safeway's frozen food aisle.  My server started off friendly and attentive and then became downright creepily intrusive.  Ironically in spite of the constant attention, my one and only minor request to hold the anchovies on the salad got lost.  5 min later there they were in all there wormy, hairy, oily glory.  Big deal?  No.  But hardly a Meg Ryan request out of Harry Met Sally.  Bigger deal when shelling out $75 for a dressed up Olive Garden.
author: Brian W.

description: This is one of my favorite Happy Hour spots. They are always rotating the type of champaign and oysters but whatever they serve is typically quite nice quality and not the cheap stuff you find at some happy hours. The regular menu looks and smells very good as well....I'll have to save room after the parmesan baked oysters on a half shell :-)
author: Megha V.

description: Had the breakfast omelet, it was ok, I have had better back home around the corner for half the price. We were in a rush to get to SFO so had to stop here, we did notice they were consistently packed a few nights before, probably mostly tourists.
author: Carlos L.

description: My daughter and her 5 girlfriends really enjoyed this restaurant for her 18th birthday dinner!  Now they want ME to try it and I will!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Hmmmmm.  Not as good as I remember

I used to travel to SF often and this was one of my favorites.  The staff is as nice as they ever were.  Had a good happy hour on wines..  But the food wasn't as good as I recalled.
author: Wayne L.

description:
I came here for an early happy hour.
It was very crowded for the holidays, but I'm sure it's quieter when the Christmas shoppers are gone. Snagged a couple seats at the bar and ordered.

I started with a pretty average well mojito, but it certainly packed a punch. I tried the crab cakes which were decent, the bruscetta  and the pizza margherita which were delicious. When I finished my first drink, I had a glass of the three dollar champagne which was great.

The bartenders where friendly and attentive, and overall I'd be happy to come back.
author: Ariel M.

description: I rarely send food back but when I ordered the clams and linguine here it was so salty it tasted like I just took a bite of the ocean. I told the waiter that it was way too salty and asked if I could order something else, he didn't complain at all and took it back at no charge and very promptly replaced it with an order of the spaghetti and meatballs which was MUCH better. The manager also came over to apologize about the first order and checked to see if the spaghetti was better. The spaghetti and meatballs were definitely good, as is the bread and dip you get while waiting for your entree. I've definitely had better Italian food in San Francisco, but if you're near Union Square this place is worth a try. Just avoid the clams and linguine unless you like your food extra extra salty.
author: Tamara M.

description:
I feel a little bad giving only 2 stars, but I feel like I have to be a little harsh on Italian places given how many there are.

So why 2 stars? I spent the entirety of the main course thinking, "Well, this is not BAD, but I can make something better than this. Actually, I usually do." 

And that's just it. The pasta wasn't bad; it just wasn't worth going back for. (We tried the signature spaghetti and meatballs, the lasagna bolognese, and the veggie lasagna. I found the textures odd and the flavors kind of bland.)

What I WOULD consider going back for is the valhrona truffle cake, the bruschetta, and the service. We were given an order of the bruschetta on the house because it was our first time at the restaurant (maybe because we made an opentable reservation?), and it really was a wonderful combination of garlicky, tomatoey, slightly chewy, balsalmicky, goat cheesey goodness. The wait staff was attentive, and the melty melty chocolate cake was SO good. I might go again for dessert or a light bite, but probably only if I were already in the area and had forgotten about the price/value breakdown (which is not so good in my book).

Sorry guys; I had been really looking forward to trying this place because from the outside it looks like a fun and tasty Italian place. Now I know...
author: Liz E.

description: One of the more reliable choices in the Union Square area. Efficient service, good but not spectacular food and reasonable (for San Francisco) prices.
author: Mike D.

description: This place is close to work so therefor one of my favorite spots for Happy Hour. Who can't love a $3 glass of champagne?!?! Everything I've had has been good and the service is always great! Love this place!
author: Heather B.

description:
The city is dotted with Italian restaurants and most are not too shabby, including this one. It's worth a shot if you're looking for a nice sit-down, grander meal than usual.

Saturday night, 6:30pm-

Environment: busy and alive! Even from the outside, the interior seemed warm and inviting. The decor creates a super homey experience. 

Food: Warm spinach salad and pear pizza. Wonderful dishes. 

Warm spinach salad--spinach, peppers, goat cheese, mushrooms tossed in warm balsamic vinaigrette. Delicious; a little over-dosed with vinaigrette and slightly wilted spinach, but still a good salad. 

Pear Pizza--gorgonzola, pear, pancetta, arugla. Crispy, thin crust, and what interesting mix of topping flavors. 

Dessert: (recs from the waiter who gave us very honest suggestions about everything). Valhrona Truffle Cake (his favorite): warm molten, extra gooey super chocolatey truffle with a scoop of vanilla gelato in the center. Chocolate lovers, this is for you! 

Affogato (espresso shot and vanilla gelato): simple, classic, good. 

Staff: We had a lovely waiter. Patient and helpful with all the questions we had about the dishes on the menu. 

Prices: I'd have to say a little pricey, but it's great quality ingredients so some say it'd be worth it... or at least on occasion :)
author: Karen W.

description:
I came here over the weekend for my birthday and had an amazingly delicious dinner. My boyfriend and I came in around 5:30ish and only had to wait about 5 minutes (score!).

We started out with the bruschetta - slices of bread with stewed tomatoes, basil, and goat cheese, all drizzled with a little bit of oil and vinegar. It was definitely different, I'm used to more traditional bruschetta. Still this definitely hit the spot and was really yummy.

For our main course, I had the capellini and my boyfriend had the bistecca. The capellini came with tomatoes, basil, and huge pieces of mozzarella cheese....sooo good! The bistecca came with a small salad an some mashed potatoes - my boyfriend said it was delicious.

For dessert I ordered the chocolate cake with vanilla gelato and my boyfriend ordered the creme brulee. Both were so yummy and a perfect ending to a very filling dinner.

Overall, this is a great dinner spot and very close to Union Square if you are staying in the area.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Perhaps this should be closer to 3.5 stars, but I'm feeling generous, and I suspect I'll go back again for a second try to decide if they really do deserve that 4th star.

8.30pm on a busy Friday night and we managed to seat 8 of us in their large bar area - that made me happy. Happy Hour was over by then which is a shame because they have some great HH deals, but that said, had it been HH we probably wouldn't have got seats, so you can't have it all!

We stayed in the bar area for drinks and nibbles. Bruschetta and calamari were OK, edible but far from great. Crab cakes were excellent - moist and light with a nice crispy outside, served on a bed of lettuce. The meatballs were large and quite tasty and the serving size was generous. Also had the hot chocolate truffle cake with ice-cream which was OK. 

Plenty if wines by the glass, half bottle or full bottle and they let us taste a few before deciding. That said, we didn't find any great wines, only OK ones. Same goes for the cocktails. But if I can get those same drinks for $3 during HH then I'll probably be back!

A nice find for an area I usually try to avoid (not a fan of the touristy areas), and a convenient place to stop after a hard day of shopping.
author: Izzy A.

description:
How can you go wrong with $3 glasses of champagne and happy hour from 4pm 'til close Sunday-Tuesday? Amazing!

The happy hour specials are great and the happy hour food almost better. The staff are generally very nice, and the patrons there to relax with a good drink at the end of their day. This is a favorite of my friends, and I can see why.

I'll be back! (no reference to the Governator)
author: Lauren J.

description:
I had a great time here. It is a busy restaurant in a very busy neighborhood. I had dinner with two other friends and all of our dishes were very good. It may be in a touristy location, but don't let that fool you.

The wine list is good and so are the martinis.

The manager, Ruth, knows how to work the room and pays attention to details. Our waiter Ian was very good and funny too.
author: Mark F.

description: Best local happy hour in Union Square. Last time we had a charcuterie plate, pizza, oysters, meatballs, and crab cakes. This was with three people. Everything's really reasonably priced on the bar menu. It's nice to be able to try a bunch of different things. We shared everything. They also have 3, 4, or 5 dollar beers. Red, white, or bubbles is 3 bucks. Not bad at all! Love this place.
author: Michelle W.

description: Decent service, good food, some great wine, but always packed to the gills. Really good option for this area of town. Especially if you're looking for Gluten-Free.
author: Casey G.

description:
GREAT HAPPY HOUR!!

Went for Happy hour and loved everything we ordered.  The Bruchetta was AMAZING, the calamari was tasty, and the crab cakes were some of the best I have had.  Great ambiance, great food, great service!!!  Wish we had more time on vacay to try the rest of the menu.
author: Laura J.

description:
This place was great -- wonderful service and delicious food. My mom picked the place out and I have to admit, I was a little hesitant that it would be a tourist trap, given its close proximity to Union Square. But it far exceeded my expectations.

We were celebrating my grandmother's 70th birthday and the staff treated her like royalty (chef came out to say happy birthday, complimentary champagne, the works). Months later, she still talks about the night.

I've heard the happy hour is also great here. Will definitely be going back and would recommend it to anyone looking for good Italian food and ambiance.
author: malorie l.

description: Kid friendly italian restaurant in the heart of Union Square.  Recommended by our concierge for a casual family Italian dining in Union Square.  Good pork chop good chicken Marsala.  Arugula salad was too vinegary and tangy for our taste. Kids didn't like their Mac and cheese because it was too authentic ^^. Great pizza. Service was great. Our waiter Ian was very nice. He just took off the kids mac and cheese from our bill and got us cheese pizza for no additional charge.  Overall great experience.
author: Sunny K.

description:
Location near the foot of Powell St cable car is convenient.  

Prices were high, considering the quality of food and comfort; $30 per head without wine and only water to drink.

Ambience is quite lacking in charm; worn old booths whose table bases leave no room for one's feet, decor, such as there is, appears amateurish and shabby.

The green salad was fresh and crisp with a nice vinaigrette.  

Minestrone was pretty good, broth-based and full of vegetables.

The risotto was also good.

The bread was the among of the worst I have ever had in a restaurant- baked in a sheet cake pan and sliced into strips; soft crust; dry and feeble crumb and tasted like day old or more - served with olive oil and capers.
author: Bruce T.

description: A Peroni on draft with parmesan fries from the all-day happy hour bar menu was a pleasant ending to our date night. We also enjoyed the Caesar salad from the bar menu which included several other appetizers for under $7. And for desert, the strawberry cheesecake was phenomenal. It's always good fun to people watch on this busy intersection on Market street.
author: Fabian S.

description:
Update: after my previous (bad) review the GM sent me a message. 

Stars for the effort. I've worked in a restaurant before so I understand when there are off nights. Appreciated the fact that they made the extra effort to reach out. Made me feel a tad guilty for giving a bad review! I do admit though (even in my last review) that the service is great here.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Puccini & Pinetti has the BEST BRUSCHETTA EVER!! My husband and I were amazed with the perfect combo of goat cheese, garlic stewed tomatoes, olive oil, & balsamic vinegar. We're only in town for 4 days and plan to return to P&P before leaving. The Tuscan Lasagna was good too & our server, Jason, was super nice.
author: Nicole H.

description: I have to say the food was great. I had the pork chop, which was just awesome. The taramisu was amazing. We haven't made it back for Happy Hour yet.
author: Noe T.

description:
We took a chance on P&P partially based upon positive Yelp reviews...and we were in the neighborhood.

Caesar salad: Actually quite good. Well dressed, creamy and house-made Caesar dressing.

Minestrone soup: Brothy and boring. Skip it.

Grilled Vegetable Panini: Tastes similar to a sandwich from Whole Foods. Costs 3x as much.

Pappardelle: I love this shape of noodle, and it was well cooked, slightly al dente. Came in a very lemony cream sauce, which was a bit too lemony for my tastes. 

Service: Attentive and polite; didn't knock our socks off but certainly did his job. 

Average is definitely the word to describe Puccini & Pinetti... average food, average service, average atmosphere. And, of course, well above average prices. Not worth the money for food-court style Italian, in my book.
author: Kate S.

description:
I can only attest to the awesomeness that is HAPPY HOUR on Monday & Tuesday. I can understand why they only offer this sweet deal 2 days a week... but you'd better believe I'll be there like clockwork on both days.

Get this:
Monday-Tuesday Happy Hour from 3pm-10pm!! $3 wine and half-off their exceptional list of bar food and appetizers. A twosome can get pretty lit and full for under $20 here. It's amazing, I know.

It obviously gets pretty busy during these times, so get prepared to hawkeye people out of their cozy bar tables. Most people here are tourists (it's connected to a hotel in Union Sq, what'd you expect?!) and they'll vacate their seats if you so much as flash a high heel or laptop case in their direction. They know you mean business. It's Happy Hour.

My suggestion if you plan on coming here a lot is to tip big. Because it's so cheap, and because the poor waitstaff gets stiffed all day by European tourists, leave a solid+ tip. You can do it, you cheap skate.
author: Rachel L.

description:
My five big stars are for their happy hour, not their main restaurant, which is a little too pricey for Italian food.

But happy hour? Glorious. Order a $3 glass of champagne and a $5 plate of warm goat cheese bruschetta. Lather, rinse repeat.
author: Nicole R.

description:
We enjoyed our lunch here. It's an authentic Italian eatery, attached to a very cool little boutique hotel. Within walking distance to Union Square, and very open feeling as it has large windows looking out onto either side of its corner location. This made for good 'people watching' on a Saturday afternoon, as the streets were crowded.  

First off, the wine selections were wonderful. They offered a McMurray Pinot Noir for $7 a glass.  This is a deal, considering we've seen it sold for almost $14 a glass elsewhere.  We ordered the bruschetta, and I would not say it was my favorite.  The portion was a bit small, but the goat cheese and sauce were very flavorful. However, the bread and tapenade they serve when you sit down were outstanding!  I'd skip the bruschetta next time and just order more of that awesome bread.  

The spaghetti and meatballs were really savory. Not the typical red sauce you'd expect to find in an Italian restaurant.  Heavier on the meat, less on the tomatoes.  Delicious, and the portion size was generous.   There was shaved parmesan cheese on top. Just enough for taste, and not over-powering. 

Our friends had the Frutti di mare, and raved about it.  I sampled one of the mussels and it was fresh and very tasty.  

The service was wonderful.  Attentive, and friendly.  We were surprised to notice later that our waiter was also the bartendar.  He did a great job keeping up with both, and we didn't even notice.  As we left, the restaurant was filling up, so I assume there was probably more staff at that time.  They had the classic t.v. show "The Streets of San Francisco" playing at all times in the background (silently with sub-titles).  Nice touch.  Very retro.  

I'd recommend this place for sure.  Not too expensive, and they are offering a coupon deal right now on yelp.  Enjoy!
author: Carolyn K.

description:
Since we were staying at the Parc 55 across the street, my husband and I stopped in here for a drink and a snack a couple days ago. 
The ambiance was very nice. We selected a corner seat in the bar area and settled in. After a couple of minutes a waitress went to the table next to us and made a large gesture to us with both thumbs over her shoulders to a waiter at the bar. Uh oh. My take was that she was frustrated that she had to tell her colleague that he needs to notice his new customers. 
The waiter came over, and we placed our order for drinks and a carpaccio. The drinks came, the carpaccio did not. Eventually, the waiter came by and said, "Uh, did you order something to eat?" We reminded him of the carpaccio. He apologized, and it came shortly thereafter.
My husband's mojito did not taste very good. He asked the waiter if he could trade it for another drink, and the waiter agreed readily. We were not charged for the icky mojito. That was good.
Overall, despite the somewhat clueless but nice waiter, I really liked this place. I enjoyed staying at the Parc 55 as well, so chances are, we will be back when we're in town.  The carpaccio was very good, so I am interested in trying their main entrees.
author: Donna D.

description:
My friend mentioned how yummy this place was.  This friend has great experience with her entrees.  My boyfriend who loves Italian, especially pasta, so we went there for his belated birthday dinner.  I would give this place 3.5 stars if I were allowed to.

This place is yummy for their entrees, but I don't know about their appetizers and desserts.  Their bruschetta was pretty good but not what we expected from the usual bruschetta.  This one has grilled tomatoes and basil pieces sprinkled, and sits next to the grilled bread.  

Mista salad was way too salty and acidic, and I swear there was no balsamic vinegar in there like the menu said.  Pappardelle and Bistecca were yummy entrees.  It was perfect except the side of arugula in the Bistecca has way too much salt.  I was literally eating granules of salt.  Dessert was creme brulee...sugar was burnt and still served.  Underneath the sugar top, the custard tasted more like eggs than vanilla.  Eck....

Recommendation, entrees and drinks here only!  By the way, happy hour only lasted until 6PM on Fridays.
author: Linda C.

description: Loved the environment and friendly service. The chicken panini for lunch was excellent. We will return.
author: Tim R.

description:
I live above this place, and we're never ever going to eat there again. Got food poisoning the first night we went after signing the lease to our new apartment.

Stay away, far far away.
author: Mike G.

description:
Amazing place!!! Great happy hour!! I believe they have happy hour everyday, but depending on the place, time varies. My friends and I split a bunch of appetizers, they were all good and cheap. I would love to come back to order from the full menu. 

5 STARS for the restaurant:  very spacious and clean!!! I love the location too!!!

4 STARS for the food: great wine and great apps!!!
author: Cnn F.

description:
So my first experience was OUTSTANDING. Our waiter was amazing!! (I wish I could remember his name!) He was funny and really on top of his game, especially for a BUSY Saturday night. The food was delicious. I had the Chicken Marsala (worth trying). No complaints. 

So a few months later, a group of 6 of us decided to head over there. From having such a positive experience the first time around, why not go back, right? Oh how wrong I was. 

Our waiter was AWFUL! The most unfriendly, unhelpful person ever. Every other person in that restaurant assisted us but our waiter. The only time we saw him was to take our drink order (20 minutes to receive them) and to take our food order. 

The food took about an hour to hit the table, refills on drinks... never happened. Complaint to the manager was a must. Having been a server myself, I know what it's like to be slammed with tables on a busy night. BUT HAVE A SENSE OF URGENCY!! I have the sneaking suspicion that he slacked off due to the fact that the table was an auto gratuity (tip is added to the check). 

We long story short, the manager comped the bills and promised to "speak" with the waiter. Don't know what good it did because after their little talk the waiter finally started serving us, in the most condescending, sarcastic tone that made me want to punch him in the face (clearly upset he lost his tip). 

Awful Awful Awful. I don't know if I can return here. 

2 stars for our first visit!
author: Ashlee G.

description: In town for a girls trip, really cool happy hour, $1 oysters and excellent service by Kevin the bartender!
author: Lauren F.

description: This rating is based on their happy hour alone.  I met some girlfriends here on a weeknight for their happy hour, which runs until closing on Mon/Tues/Sun.  By checking in on yelp, we also got a free bruschetta appetizer.  It was different from what I'm used to and had stewed tomatoes rather than fresh, and burrata cheese, yum!  I really enjoyed their version, and I'm sure it being free didn't hurt.  We also ordered a fig, arugala and panchetta pizza for $5 of the HR menu.  The pizza was solid, but not out of the ordinary.  In addition to our free bread and $3 glasses of house red wine, we walked out paying about $12-13 each, including tip.  The waitstaff was responsive, the bar area was comfortable, not too loud, and had tvs.  I'd definitely come back for happy hour!
author: Amy K.

description:
Eh.  OK, fine, it was attached to my hotel and allowed me to mow on some food after 11 hours of travel while I waited for my room to be ready.  They had a pesto pizza and draft beer.  I had 20 bucks.  It was a smooth exchange.

But afterward, I just felt dirty.  Staff were great, charming even.  But the food, even as it tried to lure me with room service in my hotel upstairs, couldn't get me back within a solid seven days, even with what I considered to be a dearth of walkable (meaning 10 minutes' walk or less) dining nearby.  Jaws were closed, ya know what I mean?

It was a one-afternoon stand.
author: Meghan B.

description: Potatoes were meh, benedict very good though eggs a bit runny.  Better than overdone!  Good happy hour.  Friendly, fast service.
author: Julian H.

description:
I hosted my wedding rehearsal dinner at P&P and it was great! I booked a party of 25 people and the reservation process was smooth. The email communication was clear. I like the menu selection and our guests had a great time. The molten chocolate cake with gelato was a big hit. 

And I like the friendly atmosphere and no minimum charge for large party! I considered hosting the rehearsal dinner at First Crush but that place has a very high minimum charge. With the money I paid, P&P is definitely as good as it gets. :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
We stopped by for a late meal just before closing on a sunday night. We ordered the mussels, beet salad, and pear and pancetta pizza.  All we were totally full of flavor and satisfying.  The mussels were cooked in a light but spicy tomato sauce and served w/ crostini, the beet salad was fresh and not too earthy, and the pizza was surprisingly delicious and rich! However, the gem of the evening was the Creme Brule, which was both prepared and cooked perfectly.  It was thick and rich in both flavor,  texture and consistency.  It was also well tempered with a crisp crunchy top.  

The restaurant was busy and the service was slow and relaxed.  The vibe was upbeat and fun and the place was buzzing with lots a good energy.  If your in the area, Puccini & Pinetti is a great place to grab a meal...

Delicioso Approved!
author: Foodie D.

description: Superb service. Our server was very attentive, cool and funny. The food And wine is good.
author: Tina F.

description: Didn't know what to expect but my entire family really enjoyed our evening. Had the linguine $ clams and really enjoyed it. Thanks especially to Jordan who took great care of us. Great work!
author: Larry H.

description: I came here for happy hours.. for the bruschetta and wine. Until the waitress hurried us up because her shift was over and then proceeded to take our credit cards and say "you know this doesn't include tip RIGHT?" Lady are you serious? Have I never gone to a restaurant before to know that after you swipe my card and I get a receipt then I add your tip. Her attitude ruined my experience and we took our business somewhere else .
author: Tegan C.

description: Have been to P and P many times over the last five years as my son was in school at SF State.  Every meal has been memorable!!!  My latest visit was just before Christmas and a friend and I each had a salad and then shared the Arrabbita.  Wow!!!  It was amazing.... the preserved lemon was outstanding!   We loved our meal and loved the wine that was recommended....  I will continue to return to this warm and inviting restaurant!!!
author: Kitty M.

description:
Good spot for Happy Hour after work. A few blocks from Powell Bart station. Go early. It gets packed!

Appetizers decently priced (about $5 each). Try their anti-pesto.
$ 3 Champagne, wine and beer. $4 well drinks
author: crystal e.

description: Wow! Incredible brunch menu! Highly recommend the crab cake Benedict! Yum! Great bloody Mary's too!!!
author: Angie A.

description:
I'll admit. I was surprised to see that this place only has 3.5 stars...I probably wouldn't have come here if I had consulted Yelp first. 

I'll let you know that I came during Happy Hour. On Monday/Tuesday, they have HH from 4pm-10pm. Got here around 6 and it was packed... went to another place for HH and then came back. Got a couple tables near the bar for our group of 12. HH pricing is amazing: $3 champagne, wine and beer. $4 for bruschetta, Caesar salad, pizza and lots of other yummy foods. 

I don't know about the dinner menu, but the HH is menu is pretty darn wonderful.
author: Rosemarie d.

description: Unfortunately I can't really base my review on the food itself because we were so distracted by the 4 children that were NOT being watched by their parents and running around and screaming.  The food was good, but not amazing, and it was pretty pricey.  All in all, it was an OK experience, but nothing incredible.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Terrible Service and Food

I had the worst Gnocci I have ever had.  The Waitress was rude when she was serving and totally ignored our table of 5.  Beware, they force an 18% tip for tables of 5 and over, so there was no incentive for her to treat us with respect.   
There are plenty of better Italian resturants around Union Square!  Don't eat here.
author: Eileen S.

description: Really great place. Service and food are really good and the bruschetta is simply the best I ever had!
author: Rodrigo K.

description: Great HH and oysters on the half shell or Parmesan baked!
author: Wendell A.

description:
Came here for happy hour on a Thursday night, but didn't make it in time, so we still got the happy hour appetizers and had to pay full price for drinks. 

Most of what I tried was good, but not great, meaning I'd still order them: caesar, breaded mozzarella, meatballs, margherita pizza, cheese plate (interesting dipping cheese and whole almonds in honey), and bread pudding (not a happy hour item).

I'd recommend the crispy calamari, fries (sprinkled with a little garlic, goes well with the orange aioli sauce), and crab cakes.
author: Diana Y.

description: Loved our meal at Puccini & Pinetti! I had the alfredo with prosciutto...it was stellar! I loved that it was a relaxed environment, yet it was still busy. We sat at a table where we could watch action in the open kitchen. It was fabulous! Highly recommend!!!
author: Amanda P.

description: For.breakfast only have ~9 things to choose from. The omelette was fine. The hash potatoes were bland as hell. But they fill mimosas to the brim!
author: Kasey H.

description:
This is our go to restaurant when in the city and haven't put thought into making reservations elsewhere. Not the fanciest place around but always good quality food and reasonable prices to boot. During our last visit I had their signature dish, Chicken Marsala, and the wife had  the Short Ribs. Both were presented beautifully and were deelish.

Service has always been good but not grreat. If you find yourself in the Union Square area go ahead and try it out.
author: Rey G.

description:
Our waiter was great...unexpectedly attentive!  I asked for extra sauce for both the calamari & for my entree, the lasagna....both times he was more than willing to bring me more sauce. 

For our appetizer we had Crispy Calamari with spicy tomato aioli. The Calamari was crisy & the aioli sauce was super good. For my entree I had the Tuscan Lasagna, which was the best lasagna I have ever had & the portion was huge. My friend ordered the grilled Tuna, which he said was amazing. I am not a fish eater, but I tried the romesco sauce that was on it...it was awesome. 

The food was much more authentic than I remember our meal at Kuleto's being. All of the dishes I saw being served looked great & the portions were large. 
I would definitely return!
author: SF M.

description:
I have been here several times and I have yet to be overly disappointed.  Their Happy Hour menu is GREAT!  SUPER cheap and more than freakin spiced nuts and french fries.  We had their white sangria and that was pretty good, although I would have appreciated a little less ice in it.  It was chock full of ice.  At $9 a glass, it wasn't much of a deal...  The $3 beer and wines are though!  Plus on I think Monday and Tuesday (?) their happy hour goes until 10 pm!  

There is also a server there who's name I cannot remember but she was AMAZING!  We went there for last summer's Dine About Town to celebrate two of our friends getting into Grad school and when we told her that she brought us a  complimentary appetizer and bottle of wine!  Needless to say we're fans now lol...
author: Jammir G.

description: Great, cute little Italian place - where the food is top notch. When starting make sure you get the antipasti, fritto misto, and parmesan fries! Each one is better than the next (the best being the parmesan fries). Then if they have it (it was a special when we went) you have to get the grilled Mahi Mahi with poached pears and goat cheese. Extremely flavorful, delicious, and probably the healthiest of all the options on the menu. Another great option is the chicken marsala (I stole a piece from my friend). Rich, tender and packed with flavor. Yes, I know I keep repeating the word delicious and flavorful - but those are the only two words that I can use to describe this food!
author: Crissy H.

description: We came here for lunch today. Nice ambience, good seating, moderate crowd for noon on a Sunday. Ordered the bruschetta, margherita pizza, warm spinach salad and capellini - the complimentary bread was not warm and we were a bit concerned how the rest of the meal was going to be. The dip that came with the bread was delicious though. The Bruschetta arrived next - toasted bread slices drizzled with balsamic glaze and served with a generous heap of chunky stewed tomatoes and a large dollop of warm goat cheese spread - just awesome!  The pizza was good, though it left a slight aftertaste. The spinach salad was warm with roasted peppers and fresh spinach - simple and delicious. We saved the Capellini for later. Our server Saul was nice, kept checking on us and kept our waters filled. Not long of a wait for the food to arrive, reasonable prices and good food. Would recommend to friends.
author: Vidhya H.
