description: A great place to drop by when you're near Union Square - it's steps away from the Powell Bart station. There was a lively bar at happy hour and the lasagna served at dinner was perfectly al dente. Make sure not to miss their seasonal pumpkin cheesecake in the fall!
author: Angela L.

description: Our team went on Tuesday for Christmas Party. We had amazing time, they set us in the back of the restaurant so we had some privacy. Food was delicious and our waitress was very  service oriented. Highly recommend this place for large parties and small.
author: Pureorganic S.

description: Our running group has had dinner here every time before the Nike women's half marathon. We have always had great service and great food. This year we booked the reservation 3 months in advance, for 10 people. We only had 6 people, but the manager decided to give up our reservation and we had to wait over an hour! When the manger comped us appetizers he only gave us half size portions. Our waitress and food was good which is why we are giving them a 3.
author: linda m.

description:
This place has a great-looking menu, and the prices lead you to expect an equally impressive meal. Alas, that wasn't our experience. 

On the positive side, we did enjoy the generous $3 glasses of wine and attentive service. 

The food, however, just wasn't anything to get excited about. Our bread was dry and bland. My seared ahi tuna was merely OK (the tastiest part of the dish was the little bit of spinach under the fish), and my colleague's roasted beet salad was so small and nearly devoid of beets that he actually laughed when it arrived.

There's so much tasty food in this city. But we didn't find it here.
author: Todd H.

description: Went here for dinner last night with my boyfriend. I was having a tough day at work and he recommended we go out to dinner in San Francisco. Finding a place to eat was a pain everywhere we went needed a reservation. Our last option was Puccini & Pinetti if we didn't want to go to a chain restaurant. We walked in and got sited right away. I ordered the Chicken Marsala which was pretty good however it lacked seasoning and my bf ordered the Spaghetti. He liked the meat sauce but even for him the food lacked flavor. The service here was descent, our waiter only approached us twice once to get our order and the second time to give us our check but there was another server who did an amazing job at making sure we were happy.  Overall the dinner was enjoyable however not memorable. I'm not sure if we would come back .
author: Nava N.

description:
wow..what a waste of time and money!

Gnocchi with butternut squash: dry dry dry! (literally P&P's version does not come with sauce) tasted like lumps of burnt dough.
 
Vegetarian lasagna: bland bland bland! 

came here for yelp drink week...pom sangria was just juice. inconsistent service. some orders were filled an inch or more under the rim (really noticeable when you order several of the same drinks)
But i like how the bathroom is located to the connecting hotel...gives you a chance to get away from the food!

If you're looking for Italian, go to north beach.
author: Lynn T.

description: Don't order the $23  vegetable lasagna.  I have had better microwave lasagna that cost $3.50.  They put raw carrots and corn in it!  Raw f-ing carrots and corn.  I thought I was being punked.  It was not edible.
author: Justin C.

description:
If Olive Garden is the Walmart of Italian food, this place would be Target. Sometimes it might seem like Macy's, but don't expect Nordstrom. 

I used to bring employees here for lunch, and I take my wife here every now and then. I have eaten here over a dozen times, and I still enjoy coming here. The service is good, and consistent. I come in my suit, and in my jeans and T-shirt, and I'm still treated like they want my business either way.

The appetizers are decent. The calamari are better than any calamari I've tasted in any other restaurant, and that is saying a lot. The entrees are also good. If you want something that is not on the menu, like say, Tilapia, they will make it for you if they have it in the kitchen. If you don't like the vegetables or sides that come with your entree, they will also be open to replacing it with something you would rather have, as long as it's in the kitchen. Everyone likes the spaghetti, and although its an okay dish, I don't like spending that kind of money on something I can make at home for a buck. If you want something safe, the pizzas are AWESOME. I've had dessert here a couple of times, it's nothing special, so don't waste your money. The coffee also is nothing special, so just get your check after the entrees arrive. 

Bottom line- nice safe italian restaurant that has a user-friendly menu that anyone can read, that is nicer than Olive Garden and costs about the same.
author: Daryl Y.

description: Well i Like this place , well I like happy hour,. ok.  This right place to meet peple. its not casual , its not fining dining  but in between. wine 3.00 dlls long isnald $ 5.00 . We and my friends  had great time.. the service was great At the we end up hooking with some  people. by the way the server Kevin .  but the way . He is not server . he is good sale person there. hes cool.
author: Cesar E.

description:
Only for business. I'd only come here again if I was getting treated for a business lunch. For that type of meal, it was great. Quiet location, bright, decent food. 

However, I wasn't THAT impressed. I enjoyed my meal alright. But it wasn't the best pasta I've ever had. It's a little overpriced for not being amazing. However, I will say, the bruchetta is GREAT. I really enjoyed that our bread wasn't overly crackly and hard. And that there was an abundance of tomatoes and flavor.

Service was awkward. Our guy seemed to be better suited, in terms of attitude, to work at your local Chili's. He was just a little too nonchalant and inattentive.
author: Jon C.

description: This definitely is the best place for HH. $3 wine? I'll have 3 glasses please! The food is good too. It's hard finding a place that serves good food and cheap alky for HH, but look no more. I had the baked oysters-love it! If you want them raw or baked they're only $1 each so knock yourself out. I think I had half a dozen. The crab cakes were decent, and my favorite pizza came with housemade Italian pork sausage, caramelized onion, marinara, mozzarella, arugula...another thing I love Italian pizza mmm. The fritto misto was okay. I didn't even know they had mussels and fries here for HH. but that gives me a reason to come back. I wish this place was bigger in terms of the HH section, but I always leave here satisfied.
author: Diane L.

description: First night in town and I was on the hunt for a delicious and fulfilling meal. I ordered the chicken Marsala and truly it was fantastic. The gravy was very flavorful and the chicken was perfectly moist, which can be hard to do when it's thin. Would definitely go back!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Intrepid Yelper Emily "Industrious" J. has a handy list -- called BARTable -- of good eats within walking distance of a BART station. And I would put Puccini & Pinetti high on that list. Of course, there are dozens if not hundreds of places within striking distance of Powell Street station, but P&P looked especially inviting as I strolled off BART toward my hotel.

I was in town for an evening business meeting, so up to SFO from LAX that afternoon, then back home the next morning. I had an hour to kill before the meeting, and what better way than with a couple of happy hour beers for a reasonable $3.50 each at P&P?

For good measure, I ordered the beet salad, which was tasty, though rather pedestrian in its presentation. 

The waiter was friendly and downtempo (the result of a lingering hangover, would be my guess), the music unobtrusive, the booth comfortable, and the free WiFi signal strong. 

No better way to get caught up with work e-mail than over a couple of happy hour beers and a light salad. 

If I'm in the area, I'd probably pop in again.
author: Aaron M.

description: Wow, a fantastic dinner and a fun place with a great atmosphere.  Sat at the bar and ate dinner there...wife had linguini and clams, and I had rigatoni with fennel sausage.  Food was great...pasta al dente just as it should be with just the right amount of spice on the rigatoni.  Wife said the linguini and clams was one of the best versions she's ever had.  The bartenders are friendly and pour a very stiff drink...loved the Negronis!  Puccini and Pinetti is a great place to have a fun dinner if you are in Union Square.
author: David S.

description:
LOVED!
Starters:
Crispy Calamari- probably the best I have EVER had and heard its the best in the city and it was!!!!
Bruschetta- delicious!  the bread was so good and everything together was perfection!

Main Courses:
Frutti di Mare- my husband LOVED this dish!  He said all the seafood together was like a party in his mouth.  I definitely need to go back and try this.
Filet Mignon- Steak was cooked to perfection (medium) and was one of the best cuts of steak I think I have ever had.  The risotto under the steak was yummy too!!
Short Rib- my cousin orders this here all the time.  Says its the best! (it looked delicious!)

I had two pom martinis- great!  And we had two bottles of Chianti- perfect for our dinner.  We were stuffed and didn't have room for desert.  I heard to order something called the "Warm & Gooey" not sure what it is, but next time I am in San Fran- i'm going with an empty stomach so I can eat so much more!

p.s. we came in jeans and didn't feel under dressed- even more of a bonus!
author: Lindsey B.

description:
Food was fabulous, service extra attentive!!  We are in SF for my husband's job and I wanted to find a place to go celebrate our anniversary with a high chair for our 17 month old.  Tough to cross great (non-chain) food and high chair.  The beet and garden salad were great, nice portion, fresh ingredients, a bit heavy on the dressing but it was tasty!

We ordered the butternut squash risotto and short ribs.  Again, healthy portions and cooked to perfection --meet melted in our mouths and risotto cooked perfectly and shaved parm blended so well with the cubes of butternut squash.  

I had noted on the online reservation, that it was our anniversary, and they brough us glasses of champagne, so nice!!  Our dinner came out quickly, but not rushed and since we had the little guy, we didnt stay for dessert but the manager came over with something to go for us (and utencils!).  Really above and beyond, I'm super impressed.  It was tiramisu which was really good.

Since we live in LA, probably won't come back but there were a lot of things on the menu that sounded really good and though we were there with a toddler, there were many groups of couples, some women out on the town, and friends out for a fun night.
author: Sac B.

description: This place was great.  My pork chop was phenomenal and so was my chocolate souffle!  Wine recommendation was good.  Will be back when I'm in town.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Please note that I haven't had dinner here.  I'm just reviewing the Happy Hour.  Based upon the mixed reviews for dinner on yelp, I would most likely pass on dinner.  Besides, with the wide selection of choices on the Happy Hour menu, there is really no need for dinner.
One of my friends at work recommended we try out this spot for happy hour on a Tuesday evening.  Wow!  I was impressed at the variety of small bites and appetizers that were on the menu for anywhere between $3 and $7.  The white and red wine is $3 a glass and the champagne is $3!  They also have various beers averaging about $4 a pop.  
We each ordered, ahem, about 3 glasses of red wine, which was a decent cab.  We also ordered the cheese plate, the crystal hot sauce chicken tenders, the house marinated olives and the Italian meatballs.  My favorite was the crystal hot sauce chicken tenders, because I'm partial to Crystal Hot Sauce.  But, seriously, for the prices, the food was a good value and tasted really good.
Our server was super-friendly and very attentive.  We weren't waiting at all to get refills on our wine!  Wednesday through Friday, happy hour goes until 6:00, it's all day on Saturday and Sunday and on Mondays and Tuesdays, it's 3PM to close!
I will be going back for Happy Hour again.
author: Bethany D.

description:
My two nieces and I met at Puccini and Pinetti for their happy hour on 7-26-2011 at 6:30 p.m.   I first ate here about 10 years ago when staying at the Hotel Nikko and then later when seeing a theatre show in the area.  I've always like their menu and casual but kind of funky decor. 

The night we went, it was crowded which I expected becaue it was happy hour and on certain nights (like Tuesday) happy hour goes from 3 p.m. to closing!  I managed to get us a great corner window table in the bar section within about 15 minutes (by talking to the guys still at the table into telling me when they were leaving) which meant we didn't have to wait for 45+ minutes to be seated in the restaurant section (as we forgot to make a res).  Once we sat down, or should I say swooped into that table and chairs once the guys left... we were promptly greeted by a friendly waitress, given menu's and she took our drink orders. We ordered three appetizers (2 of each) from the very affordable Happy Hour List.  We shared brushetta, crab cakes w/salad, and meatballs as our dinner.  The crab cakes were very tasty and had a great aioli sauce, but they didn't look like the traditional shape/size of a CC.  These were more the size and shape of golf balls.  Regardless, they were good and one of my nieces (who never had crab cakes) liked them, so that was a plus.  The brushetta and meatballs were also good.  Two pieces of brushetta per plate and a lot of meatballs in each bowl with a sufficient amount of tasty red sauce.  With 4 drinks and six appetizers the bill came to about $70.  Since we had planned to get pedicures (at $60 a pop ea) and decided to have drinks and eat instead, I was happy to pay only $70!   Best parking is the Ellis/O'Farrell Garage.  Their address is 123 O'Farrell, but I believe you enter on Ellis and exit on O'Farrell.  For the 2+ hours one niece was there, she only paid $6 to park just a few blocks away so that was a plus.
author: Debra G.

description: Great happy hour all night on Monday and Tuesday.  Very friendly staff, lively and comfortable.  The appetizers aren't bad and are reasonably priced.
author: K P.

description:
Surprisingly good for a pasta joint in touristville central.  Reasonable prices and portions - open fairly late too (past 10p).

Bf enjoyed his spag & meatballs and my pasta w tomatoes, basil and fresh moz was tasty.
author: Emily W.

description:
We decided on dinner here to celebrate me and my mom's birthday.  We started in the bar for happy hour, which is all evening on Mondays.  We both had a lemon drop martini and it tasted like straight lemon juice.  It was not good at all.  However, that was the ONLY thing that was not good!  In the bar we had the crab cakes (amazing!!, wish they had them as an entree option!), calamari (which was also very, very good), and my dad had the oysters.  He said they were the absolute best.

We then moved over to the dining room for dinner.  I had the chicken marsala and it was very, very good! my mom had the spaghetti and meatballs and said it was very good as well..the service was good and the best part was the prices.  I thought they were very reasonable for happy hour and dinner!  Granted, after having appetizers in the bar, my husband and I shared an entree and a salad, so that is why it was a little less expensive than normal, but we were full and it was a great place!  

We will be coming back!
author: Erika L.

description:
After going to happy hour here a couple of times. I decided to finally give Puccini & Pinetti a try for dinner. I was excited to bring my friends here since I had such a great experience with their happy hour menu. I was hoping for the same experience with their dinner menu. 

The meal started out great with the appetizers. We had the calamari and the mussels - both were delicious. I've tried them both for the happy hour menu and knew that they were going be a hit with this group. Moving on to the entrees was when things got a little funky. Out of everything I decided to play it safe with lasagna.  At a Italian restuarant you can't go wrong with lasagna!  But I guess I was wrong.  I had the herb lasagna and was very disappointed.  They had actual herb leaves in the lasagna and it overpowered the whole flavor of the dish. The herb leaves were actually so dominant that I couldn't even taste the cheese and sauce. The rest of the party had a mix of pasta dishes and steak and they all had complaints. 

Definitely sticking to the happy hour menu. For a group of 7 our bill came out to around $230 with the 18% gratuity. We all walked out of there unsatisfied with $40 less in our pocket.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Food was favorable and cooked perfectly
Service was attentive and responsive
Location has good vibe (even if you come alone)
author: Raymond F.

description:
This is just for happy hour. The place has a happy hour every night including Sunday from 5-close (even on Valentine's Day). Stopped here for a night cap drink as it was right across the street from the hotel. At about 9:30 the place was still bustling - great sign! 

Drinks: Sat at the bar and received great service! Drinks were strong and inexpensive ($4 range). 

Food: Saw one of the cooks making a margherita pizza and just had to try it - even after just gobbling down dinner...It was yum! and only $5. Did not try other food and not sure if I would as the menu seemed pricey for what it was.

Great little spot!
author: Jason C.

description: Pretty good place for happy hour. Kinda happening. The appetizers were dent and the pork chop was ok - a bit overcooked. I wouldn't rush here for dinner but it was fine to hang out with friends.
author: Josh B.

description: This place advertises a gluten free menu. Well my girlfriend and I ate from their gluten free menu (pasta dishes) and it made us both extremely sick. It ruined the whole next day for my girlfriend and about the next 3 days for me of our vacation. Plus dinner cost over $100. Not only that, but the spaghetti and clams I ordered was so spicy is was inedible. Do not eat here if you have a sensitivity or an allergy to gluten. They should stop offering a gluten free menu until they learn how to do it right. We're extremely disappointed and angry that they ruined a big chunk of our vacation.
author: Kevin B.

description: Love their reduced price happy hour appetizers.  The frito misto used to have fennel and lemon also fried with the calamari.  I miss that in the dish.  Still yummy!
author: Heidi T.

description:
Went here during a weekend trip to the City. I chose it specifically because I have celiac disease and  it was listed as a gluten free restaurant. They even had a gluten free menu online with a variety of pastas with different sauces. I thought it would be great. What a joke. When I got there they said yes they had gluten free pasta although they only had it in spaghetti noodles. Sure is difficult to make the ravioli on the gluten free menu with spaghetti noodles, therefore I chose the spaghetti and meatballs. I asked if they meatballs had wheat as a filler, since they usually do, and was told no. I asked about the minestrone soup on the gluten free menu since it should have pasta noodles in it. They said it did have noodles and that they weren't gluten free. Glad I asked. Why is it on the gluten free menu??? When I got my sphagetti the waiter said he double checked and that the meatballs did have wheat as a filler so he left them off. In the end I got spaghetti and marinara sauce. Not quite what I'd expected. This restaurant kind of decided to jump on the gluten free bandwagon wihout any understanding of what they were doing. Lucky if they don't make someone real sick someday. I talked to the manager about all this and he said he could understand my concerns and would see what they could do in the future. I won't hold my breath.

Oh, the other people in my party weren't gluten free and they were under impressed with their normal items. Considering I went to Restorante Bacco the next night, where the manager has been gluten free for four years and the menu was fantastic for gluten free and non gluten free diners, this one was a real swing and a miss.
author: J H.

description:
This place was just A-OK.  There was a long wait on a weeknight which was surprising, but promising...the hostesses, however, were kind of rude...appeared as though we were just making their night longer.

The food was good...not great, but just good.  I had the seafood stew which was a poor man's cioppino. BONUS: I liked that they allowed for half orders which allowed me to have a salad with my meal for the same cost as a whole entree order.
author: Mr. And Mrs. G.

description:
When I rate my dining experience for Italian, I always base it off my experiences eating Italian in the North End in Boston.  

I ordered the Capardelle (not on the online menu for some reason).  It was actually quite tasty.  I tried to order Guiness but they ran out of it, and took another beer.  $20 for the entree, $6 for the beer.

While having reasonable food, the ambience and price leave something to be desired.  It's a large restaurant so privacy is non-existent.  They have a limited beer selection as well, and not exactly a bang for your buck place.

I'll take friends elsewhere next time.
author: Neil P.

description: very salty but ok, has a Gluten free menu!
author: Tracy O.

description: went for breakfast on vacation, potatoes were amazing. Fast service, would definitely go back.
author: Maria B.

description:
If there was an inspiration for Carrabba's, it must have been this place. Friendly staff, decent atmosphere. I sat at the chef's counter to avoid the wait and enjoyed watching the chefs working the line. 

Calamari to start, well cooked not rubbery at all, but slightly greasy. The dipping sauce didn't really blow me away, some sort of mayonaise based lemon cayenne thing. Ho hum.

The ribeye was a bit on the thin side and had a bit too much of char for my taste.... Especially with my order of medium-rare (more rare than medium). Usually steaks come out with very light grill marks, but watching the guy it looked like my steak was on fire the whole time. Grilled = good, charred = bad. The sides were good enough, smashed potatoes with olive oil. Well seasoned and the perfect consistency. Arugula salad, nothing special...it's hard to mess up arugula anyways. There was some sort of shallot butter, didn't really taste shallots or butter.

The food isn't bad, but it's not great either, but it's totally overpriced. For this money I'm going back to Perbacco.
author: William W.

description:
One star for the nice space in the back they carved out for our group of crazies.
One star for the awesome Arrancini (breaded butternut squash risotto)
One star for the delicious Capensante (grilled scallops, with watercress, corn & frisee salad)
Two Stars for not throwing us out after the third time Lance G. yelled "CUMSLUTS" at the top of his lungs.
author: Jay Z.

description: I was here twice while in san Francisco at a conference. The first time was fine, mediocre crab cakes but good wine. The second time was on a Tuesday night, not good. I stopped in for a glass of wine, I did not know however that they closed at 10. The bartender was rude. He was unhelpful and irritable. If one is too late for service please tell them. I would have rather that than have been given sub standard service and short remarks. Very unprofessional.
author: Carma D.

description: I really like this restaurant.  It's not the most "traditional" Italian food (for that you need to go to North Beach), but it's good, not very expensive, and the service is excellent.  I went for lunch this week, and even though they had a large group there, I didn't need a reservation, and my friend and I never had to wait for anything. Our food came in 10 minutes.  After leaving, I thought I had left my sunglasses, so I called, and the hostess kindly looked for them and even took my phone number so she could contact me if they were found.  I will definitely be going back for dinner and drinks!
author: Lisa E.

description: This restaurant was conveniently attached to our hotel so we were able to enjoy happy hours before our dinners and breakfasts in the morning. The first night we came here was for happy hour and the menu prices were great and there were so many dishes to choose from. I told the bartender I was only drinking tequila and although it wasn't on the menu, he made me a happy hour margarita (thank you!). We also came here for breakfast and although the service was a little on the slow side at the time, the breakfast tasted great and the portions were huge. I also enjoyed that they had a TV broadcasting sports in the bar.
author: LuLu M.

description: Staying in a hotel across the street for a few days, and I have a feeling I will come back during this same stay. Awesome bloody served by a super funny and nice bartender. Bruschetta was delish and is served with goat cheese which was awesome. The rest of the staff was really friendly as well.
author: tara c.

description:
It's been a while since I've written a review.  For good reason, of course: I've been eating home cooked meals for the most part and have pretty much been living in seclusion...

So my b-day finally came along, and I was taken to an impromptu dinner here.  It was nice.  The service was attentive.  The drinks were a-ok.  The food was a tad bit too salty.  I had the gnocci and although good, I think I've had better gnocci dishes than the one dreamt up at this establishment.  However, I must say their creme brulee was pretty tasty!!
author: Karen B.

description:
Meh. 

The Breakdown:

* Nice place to grab Italian when you're out shopping in Union Square and have no means (or energy) to pop over to North Beach 

* Good atmosphere to chow down with mom, a friend or even have a subdued quarrel with the boyfriend

* No frills Italian-American dining with staples like Spaghetti w/ Meatballs and Lasagna 

Things to Note: 

*Grilled Caesar Salad - Whaaaat?!?! They grill the lettuce? Cah-raaazy! Nevertheless, the slight charred taste coupled with hits of salty and crunchy goodness from the crostini makes this salad a must try

* The dip they give with bread is excellent! Probably the best thing I ate for dinner there 

* Spaghetti w/ Meatballs: Spaghetti kind of bland, meatballs way too salty 

* Mushroom Ravioli: Very, very oily, but the ravioli packed major mushroom flavor 

* Calamari did not taste cooked all the way and the side of aioli was watery
author: Rebecca T.

description: Went for happy hour... best calamari ever! Long island was fantastic. Perfect location to our hotel, and friendly staff.
author: Lisa L.

description: We were a group of 4, 2 couples. We ordered a variety of their food. Neither the quantity and the quality were good. I expected a tasty unique meals, but the opposite is true. I personally do not recommend it unless you want to try the badness yourself. I'm writing negative '1 star' to share what happened to me, may be it is not the truth. Thank you for reading my review.
author: Ahmed K.

description:
Stumbled into here on a Friday night after happy hour across the street ended and got just what I needed.... good food.

Got seated right away and proceeded to dive into the menu. Started with an order of the calamari and the bruschetta.  Both were awesome (spicy tomato aoili... REALLY GOOD). Next up was my Short Rib order. Meat was tender and seasoned just right... worked really well with the pesto mashed potato. It didn't last very long on my plate. My fork also gravitated to the Pappardelle and Osso Bucco which my friends had ordered. Everything was tasting good. Add in a pomegranate sangria and that was a near perfect meal.

Special thanks to Veronica, Avery, and Ruth for making it a great time.
author: Mike A.

description:
you don't really need my review here.  It is standard fair mid range turn and burn Italian restaurant attached to a hotel.  My portabello house made ravioli with a cream sauce and frise was delicious.  The house pinot I got was, "ok".  Our server was an honest, shorter woman with glasses and a spunky attitude.  She was awesome.  The pistachio cheesecake was... interesting.  Better than I would have thought, and I can't judge as neither of those hit my palette well.  

Here's the rub... It was valentine's and a group of 5 of us had no reservation.  My partners asked, and management said they didn't have room.  He must have seen them miserably ambling about in the rain, looking confused... because he ran back out 15 minutes later and said, "We can do it!".  They set it up, took care of us... it was fantastic.  We ordered a dessert that was 86'd *AFTER* we ordered it.. and he was apologetic about the gaffe.  We cancelled our full round of desserts, yet he still brought us a couple comp treats, partially for the mistake, but mostly because "[he] couldn't let us leave without dessert."

The food was fine.  I don't know if I would venture back anytime soon... but I am downtown often and this will stick out in my memory.

It has been a long time since I have seen this, and I have worked in the industry for almost two decades....  

but the management of this restaurant "gets it".  Like... REALLY REALLY get's it.  This was one of the first times in a long time I saw service take potential gaffes and mistakes and turned them into solid responses that were customer centered and kindly deferential.  It was a pleasure to be in that experience.

cheers bald headed smiling gent.... you did a fantastic job on that "in the weeds" busy night.  I can rightly assume you have your management and staff in line the same way.

A consummate professional experience, it made me miss running a well honed restaurant.  Of course, they might not think it is... but I never saw "the man behind the curtain" and the fourth wall was completely contained.  Whether it is a well run restaurant or not, they handled it such that it obviously seems to be... which is sometimes... on some nights... all that matters.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
This bar/restaurant is right around the corner from where I work, and I have tried to go here several times, but was unsuccessful.  They have great happy hour prices, but they only serve it in the bar area which fills up quick. 

That being said I finally made it there last night!  I had a glass of red wine ($3) and the steamed mussels ($6).  I would say that everything was good, but not great, def. a good deal for the price, but nothing to write home about. The sauce, however, that my mussels came in was super flavorful and creamy! So I was excited about that.  Both my friends ordered desert.  The tiramisu was good, but the butterscotch chocolate bread pudding was a bit dry and not to butterscotchy.

I would go back though, if for nothing else than the cheap happy hour prices!
author: Dana C.

description:
Ewwww.

I can't think of another word to properly describe my two experiences here.  Oh wait, yes I can:

Meh.

Service - minimal and brusque
Cocktails - decent
Food - appetizers were decent but my salad clearly was scooped from the bottom of the bag of greens and my pasta entree could have been made better by my niece, and she can't even reach the stove yet
Atmosphere - loud, crammed, unappealing

Like I said - meh.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Perhaps because I've been reading Toni's reviews so much, I was in the mood for either a burger or calamari. And the calamari was great. Nicely fried and crunchy but without leaving me feeling weighed down and greasy. The green salad was delicate and perfectly dressed. I also had a side of asparagus... not sure why, but maybe I needed to feel virtuous by eating veggies with my fried food. 

All in all, the calamari craving was satisfied (by the way, to answer your unspoken question, Toni, there was a nice balance of rings to the tentacles, yum!). Now all I have to do is try to find somewhere to satisfy my burger craving.
author: Patty W.

description: I have been here a few times while staying in SF - around the corner at the Hotel Nikko - and it is always a solid choice.  The chicken marsala with garlic mashed potatoes is not to be missed and even though it's a cliche dessert, the chocolate lava cake with vanilla gelato is delicious.  Our waiter, Ryan, was very attentive and even had the chef cut up some raw carrots for me vegetarian daughter.  : )
author: cheryl p.

description:
I loveeeee this place. The place was pretty crowded when I came but they atmosphere was very welcoming, warm, and pleasant. Our waiter was very nice and friendly. Since we wasn't from the area, he gave us suggestions for different bars to visit and stuff- which was helpful. The food was good, the wine was good. I remember having a pizza topped with sausages and arugula for an appetizer. The bread was thin and crispy, but not burnt. Good stuff. I think we had a pasta too, a bolognese? Whatever it was, it was delishhhh! :)

Definitely heading back here when I visit the bay area again :)
author: Chau T.

description: Happy Hour rocks!!  It offers 3$ wine, and many  appetizer selections.  We chose the chardonnay for the wine, OK, fine for the price.  We ordered the calamari,shrimp deep fried appetizer.  I know it was fried, but the greasy napkins had me very worried about my cholesterol levels...  Friend ordered the oysters, which were very tasty.  the service was slow, but friendly.  Recommend this for the drinks alone, and would try the cheeseplate next visit.
author: Neice K.

description:
When my friend suggested this place before going to the theatre, I thought it might be one of those salad and French fries vegan nights, but she called ahead and showed them what was what, and they definitely stepped up. 

On the phone she asked "Is there anything you can make vegan." When they said sure, she said, "Is there anything fun and interesting, I don't want her to just have pasta with red sauce," and they assured her they could do something.

When we got there, they treated me like a little vegan princess. First they asked who was vegan, and I raised my hand, then the waiter said, is there anything special you would like and said he would send the chef over to tell me what she could do. When she came over, she suggested that the bruscetta could be made sans cheese and on the foccaccia instead of the croustini (which apparently had some dairy) and that she could make the mushroom risotto for me without the cream or whatever. I said that sounded great, and there we went. The food was quite good.  

My friends agreed that my dish was the best of all three of ours and that they were very sweet and attentive. It would be nice if they had a few items on the menu that were already vegan, but they get major vegan brownie points for being so nice and accommodating.
author: Jeani H.

description:
my food was pretty good the waiter was very nice and came to check on me often. i cant complain. 
whent for lunch on a monday will have to go back to check out other menu i tems.
 so seafood lingunie.... cant rember what it was called was good, italian soda good service good.
author: vita k.

description:
The atmosphere at Puccini & Pinetti is nice and welcoming. The staff is very friendly and the service is GREAT. The food arrived fairly quickly and our glasses were never empty because our waiter and the bus boys made a few rounds to check whether we still had water in our glasses. Also, the food was really good. I loved their bread and the dip it came with (I'm not sure what ingredients it consisted of, but it was very good!). I also liked their potato gnocchi (and no, it doesn't beat the gnocchi at "Firenze by Night", but it wasn't bad either). The only downside was the fried calamari, because it was a 'bit too salty for my taste and the dip it came with was a 'bit spicy. However, my friend, who loves spicy food, liked the calamari and the dip, so there's the difference in opinion. 

Overall, I liked this Italian place and I didn't even have to go to North Beach. :)
author: Narina A.

description: Found it on Yelp and went on Saturday when we were in Union Square because it matched our cravings and wallet. Our waitress was lovely and attentive. The food was great! My girlfriend got a Steak Panini and me a pizza and we both enjoyed our meal very much. I wish I got the panini myself because it tasted wonderful!
author: Jahan M.

description: I would HIGHLY recommend coming here for their amazing happy hour! On Mon and Tues. its 3-close, wed-fri its 3-6, sat 11:30-6 and sunday its all day. The food options for it are really good and extensive and they have some really good drink deals. It can get really crowded so come early!
author: Tyler L.

description:
A few of us at work decide to get together for a farewell celebration for a coworker.  Since we all took public transportation to get downtown, we all were late for our dinner reservation for another restaurant.  We end up walking into Puccini &amp; Pinetti without a reservation and were seated in 5-10 minutes.  While waiting for our table to be prepped, we sit at the bar and each order a cocktail:  orange creamsicle, pomegranate sangria, raspberry margarita.  The orange creamsicle tasted so much like the actual popsicle I use to eat as a kid...and the sangria was awesome.  Two drinks I'd definitely be ordering from there again.

Finally seated we take our time looking over the menu.  Our server arrives asking for our order, still not yet ready...so she says, bread is on its way.  Not even a minute later, a huge plate of bruschetta arrives.  We sit there perplexed...so is this the house bread they give everyone.  That can't be...we thought the plate was brought to us by mistake.  Ten minutes pass.  Our server hasn't come back yet to take our order.  We decide to dive in to the plate of bruschetta...couldn't let that thing be returned =)

I have never had the tomato mixture for bruschetta served warm.  I always thought it was always chilled.  It turned out be really, really good....one of the best bruschetta ever.

I ordered their signature spaghetti and meatballs, Nikki ordered the pesto gnocchi, and Britt ordered chicken marsala.  Portions were huge....the meals, tasty.  But next time I come back, I won't order the spaghetti as it didn't leave a lasting impression on me.  I'll try something dfferent.

Bill arrives...and it turns out the bruschetta was on the house!  Can't be that!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Fitting that I decide to write this review after recently arriving back from a whirlwind 3 week trip to amazing Italia.  If anyone is down for moving to Tuscany, buying a little Villa and growing grapes, message me!  

I can't even begin to put into words how amazing authentic Tuscan cuisine is.
There is nothing authentic or Italian in my opinion about Puccini & Pinetti.  In fact, in what I consider to be the insult of all insults, it's right up there with The Olive Garden.  EEK.  Sorry, but I had to say it.
Yet another typical Americanized Italian restaurant that bears no resemblance to a real Italian trattoria.

I've been here at least three times that I can remember (shame on me, I know).  I dated a guy a long time ago that loved it and so we went there frequently.  Icky icky.  

Everything I ever tried there (mainly pastas) was overly seasoned, over cooked, and just filled with cream, oil and fat.  Not tasty.  Not healthy.
The location is not my favorite either (in the very touristy area of Union Square), but in their favor, the service was always decent.

Sorry to say, but it's not even worth going just to try it out.  Save your money.   If you want any semi-real Italian, hit North Beach.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Had a wonderful visit to Puccini & Pinetti during our vacation in San Francisco! The food was fabulous. Particularly enjoyed the bruschetta, and the chicken marsala. The service was great, and our server Amanda was just wonderful. She was friendly and helped us picked just the right drinks and entrees. We will definitely come back on our next trip to San Francisco.
author: Laura H.

description: Amazing food and wonderful service.  The bruchetta was the best I have ever had.  Our server was Veronika.  Helpful and bubbly.  Excellent job on the diet coke refills  The molten cake dessert was off the hook.  It was my first time there and I WILL BE BACK..
author: Tony K.

description: Outstanding! Great food and excellent service in a dynamic yet unobtrusive atmosphere.
author: Oswaldo L.

description:
If you're looking for a 4-6pm HAPPY HOUR this is the cheap place to have it. $3 drinks and $4 appetizers. Pizza for $4, can't beat that! Wine for $3... I miss this place when I used to work at the flood building. Run down there after work and hang out for about an hour and then back to work to look at more cases.. hahaha. 

I did have a really good lunch there. Portabella Mushroom sandwich. Their lobster ravioli was tasty too!  Pizzas are not a bad choice for their price. Over all it's not bad, but like someone else said NOT AMAZING. It's hard to find amazing in San Francisco.
author: Judi K.

description:
I came here for dinner with my bf & a friend. I was looking for an italian restaurant in the area because our friend works down there. Despite the reviews on Yelp, I thought I'd try it out myself. 

We shared some fried calamari, which was decent. I had better. The complimentary bread was not bad either. It came with some kind of sun-dried tomatoes spread. 

I had the rigatoni, which I didn't enjoy that much. I thought the flavors weren't all there or that it was missing something. My bf had the Fruitti Di Mare & he really didn't like his. I tried it & agree with him. It was... BLAH! Our friend ordered the Veal over the mashed potatoes and he enjoyed it. I wouldn't come here for dinner, but maybe for drinks and appetizers. 

Our waiter/server was very nice, but didn't come around that much. I had to wave her down a couple of times, but she was really sweet. 

Overall, the food wasn't that good, but maybe it was what we ordered. Service was decent & so were the drinks.
author: Nai S.

description:
This is the place that introduced me to the best Bellini's EVER (peach puree & champagne.) I often don't like the flavor of sangria, but I have no problem throwing a glass or two of their pomegranate sangria down my throat. During happy hour, their well drinks are only $4, which explains why it gets pretty crowded during HH; lots of after-work crowds trying to drink their bad day away. Their bar menu is well priced but dinner...not so much.

I ate here during one of my vegetarian meals only days & had the grilled caesar salad (awesome flavor) and wild mushroom ravioli (mouthwatering delicious.)  The portions were just right, but I cannot say the same about the bill; I paid over $25 for those two items alone. Add in my bar tab and it was a $50 including tax and tip kind of night. My meal was good, but not that good! Damn!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Went here for the second time this year with a friend of mine. The reason for one star? We were half way done with dessert when the host came up to us, asked us how our meal was, and then told us to finish up because there was a reservation for the booth we were in!!! The waiter hadn't even brought us our check yet!  

I have never ever had this happen before and it wasn't as if my friend and I were drunk or boorish. Never ever will I go here again.
author: EE C.

description: The waitstaff, tiramisu and espresso were all excellent.  However, the Capellini I ordered as my entree was terrible - the "sauce" was just a bunch of tomato chunks, and the mozzarella cheese on top was simply lobbed off into big hunks that were partially cold from the fridge, partially warm from contact with the pasta.  Seriously some of the worst pasta I've ever been served at a restaurant.  The benevolent part of me wants to try it again so they can redeem themselves, but the practical part of me doesn't want to gamble with a relatively pricey meal when there are lots of better places to get a decent plate of noodles
author: Andrew B.

description:
We were driven, not by car but by the horrible service we got at Kuleto's to search out a new place to eat on a Friday night (since we walked out of Kuleto's - http://www.yelp.com/biz/kuletos-italian-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:Ty8FiJnF_Z2BHKfovm63bA).  We stumbled upon Puccini.  We loved it!  Amazing T-bone and spaghetti that tasted homemade -- all for a very affordable price.
 
By comparison, our server at Puccini was pleasant, helpful and attentive.  Everyone from the busboy to the manager pitched in and at the end of the night, the server who knew we were from out of town brought us two MUNI passes that another table left for her.  It was a thoughtful gesture that really helped to off-set our sour experience at Kuleto's earlier that night.  When we are back in SF in the future we will be dinning at Puccini.
author: Runt T.

description:
Biggest. Mistake. Ever.

My girlfriend and I were on Powell, hungry, and not quite feeling Pizza or crappy cafe sandwiches, so we looked at the [lunch] menu outside at dinner time, and thought, "oh, okay, regular Italian fare...whatever lets eat".

We ended up ordering salads and the pasta "special", and split creme brulee for dessert. The salad was your average, decent mixed green salad, the pasta was pretty bland (some kind of pasta with oil, sun dried tomatoes, and garlic type thing.). Dessert was pretty good. We did not order wine -- just coffee after dinner. Overall not bad, kind of satisfying, but hardly exceptional. Pretty much like Pasta Pomodoro quality, if not a tiny bit fresher. The kind of place where you go just to get food in your belly.

The atmosphere sucked. Big open dining room with nice wood, yellow sponge paint on the walls, and tourists in t-shirts with their kids. (I generally don't have a particular problem with the latter, like when you're getting pizza or something, but it kills my buzz to see drunk dudes in neon race car shirts when I'm trying to have a "nice" dinner.)

The mediocrity of it all would've been fine, but he bill ended up being like $60. $15 for our glorified aglio e olio? Are you kidding me? When I'm cranky I don't like to think about prices, but seeing the bill just made me cranky all over again.

Bottom line: Either spend half as much at Pasta Pomodoro to get pretty much the same thing, or trek up to Caffe Delucci in North Beach if you want nicer Italian food. Please don't eat here.

Update: I just looked at the pictures and their menu online. They have an appetizer called "pasta nachos". Wow. Right up there with Applebee's or Chili's or Friday's, etc. Get me some of them Southwestern eggrolls too, why doncha.

*Bleck*
author: Derek B.

description:
Last night i went out by myself for the first time....ever. but i guess this was the place to go for lone dinners like myself. There was like 4 other people sitting alone.  everyone was very friendly. I had the Raspberry balsamic Martini and the Rosemary Lemon drop Martini, 5 starts for those drinks alone, Strong and good!  my dinner was Great, and their Cheese Cake is on my top five things i would probably whore myself out for. 
Over all I loved it.
author: Nate C.

description: Overpriced tourist trap with average food.  I can't imagine them getting a lot of repeat customers.
author: jette s.

description: I've only been here for happy hour. $3 for appetizers, wine, or champagne all within 3 blocks of my office --- definitely can't complain. Their bruschetta is fresh and deeeeelish, they even have something called pasta nachos which is pretty good. The drinks come to your table pretty quickly, but it's pretty crowded & noisy.
author: Stella C.

description:
The food was excellent.  Some of the orders from our table consisted of the Warm Beet Salad, Sausage Pizza, Spaghetti and Meatballs, Risotto with Shrimp, the Sorbet Trio, a couple of dessert shots and I forget what else but the whole table was happy, happy, happy.  

Great, clean, cozy  interiors.  It was loud and festive enough inside to make us not worry about the volume of our kids and they had menu choices for the little ones - which I understand can be rare in Downtown SF.

We ended up closing the place down and they were nice enough not to kick us out and let us realize that is was going time on our own.
author: E Z.

description: Incredible happy hour albeit the food is average and the booze on sale is weak.
author: Roger H.

description:
My boyfriend made reservations on a Friday night before we saw the show 'Wicked". The cab ride from the 'Palace Hotel" was about $7, which isn't bad. Right when we walked it, we were greeted by a very nice hostess who quickly found our reservations. We were taken to our table and "Jason" was our server. 

Jason was an amazing server who never left us asking for anything (water, more bread etc). He had no issues with us sitting at our table for longer than most would. He knew were were there for the show and brought us a complimentary appetizer (bruschetta and goat cheese). He also recommended a nice champagne to go with our meal. Jason had no issues with us sharing a meal and even brought out a nice birthday (complimentary) tiramisu for my birthday.

VERY ATTENTIVE STAFF!

The bussers came by the table often and cleared our extra plates and made sure we had everything we needed.  As the night went on, we realized that we were seated in another waiters section. Instead of  being nasty to us seeing as Jason was making the tip off this table, when it was his now, he helped us when we needed something and was very nice and friendly too. (We left him $10 as rent for camping) 

The food was rich and very flavorful. My boyfriend had the short ribs and I kid you not, we cut them with a fork! AMAZING!!!!

I actually enjoyed the volume of the restaurant, as it is part of the San Fransisco atmosphere! :o)

Would we go again? YES! Do we recommend it to friends? YES!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Plain old average.

The Good:
- Fairly cheap.
- The sorbet was excellent. :p
- Free Wifi, just click accept on first page and you're set.
- The service was decent.
- Make reservations on opentable.com

The Bad:
- Soups weren't very impressive.
- Pasta wasn't very impressive.
- Around 8 by-the-glass wine selections. Nothing great.
- It's very loud inside.
- 300 feet from the Powell St / Trolly / Tourist zoo.

Everything Else:
- Bathrooms are in the Hotel next door.
- Slightly obnoxious decor.
- Wood chairs that may bug you (no padding), didn't bother me.
author: Andrew M.

description: Way too noisy!  Good service.  Food was OK, at best.  I had the special chicken parmigiana - ample size but actually burned in parts.  Caesar salad pretty good.  My date's salmon salad was good.  We were there pre-theater and they timed it well.  I won't return - SF has too many great restaurants to put up with ones that are just OK.
author: Larry H.

description:
My advice:
Bring about $10 bucks
$3 drinks
$3 pizza?!?!!?! 
$3 tip to the waiter...don't go into a 10 min discourse on that acai berry crap martini so you can get your surfboard..chilll out dude
author: Daniella B.

description: This is a great place of happy hour or any type of late-night gathering. The quality of the pasta is decent. Checking in on yelp also gave us complimentary bruschetta, which was delicious. Highly recommend the ravioli.
author: Vivien S.

description:
While walking around down town San Francisco with my wife, we stumbled upon this restaurant. The staff was friendly enough and came to the table enough times to keep us satisfied. Now, I have to admit I personally don't care for staff that is overly excited or chatty, so to me it was the right amount of attention. The food prices were reasonable and the mix drinks were well prepared. 
We ended up ordering the Bruschetta  as an appetizer, which we probably could have served as a meal on its own. The dish comes out looking like something you would expect for desert. Vibrant red garlic stewed tomatoes give the plate plenty of color and taste as sweet as candy. The soft goat cheese in the middle of the plate look like a double scoop of ice cream, and with the balsamic vinegar drizzle swirling around the entire plate resembled a chocolate drizzle found on a Sundae. 
 I had the Bucatini Arrabiata which was a hardier serving than what I was anticipating. I can't say enough about this dish other than I will need to go back for another. The heat was enough to warm you up, while the rest of ingredients add a wonderfully fresh finish to each bite. 
If you find yourself in DTSF with a bit of an appetite do yourself a favor and stop by and give this place a try.
author: Edgar P.

description: Love this place... Wicked good happy hour!!  Hit this place for sure!
author: Jodi B.

description:
Went here a bunch of times when I was staying at The Hilton. The place was always lively and the service is good. I only had appetizers and drinks, but they do have some good Martini's. It kind of reminds me of The Cheesecake Factory. I'm referring to the decor only.
The crowd is a good mix of tourist and theater goers. Everyone always appeared to be having a good time.
author: Lisa A.

description:
I could have sworn I already wrote this review, but I guess not.

I love going to places where people enjoy their jobs and are willing to have fun.  If I smile or do something goofy in an effort to make a worker smile, it almost depresses me when they're too numb to react.  The staff at Puccini & Pinetti are very pleasant.  

I arrived with my dining companion (a.k.a. "mom") around 6:00 on a Friday night.  Though the tables were full, we were offered the option of a high table or seats in front of the food prep area (complete with window for full view of the food prep).  The executive chef along with the sous chefs were very playful with each other and answered any questions we had.  

Our food was fantastic.  The squash soup was incredibly delicious.  It was sweet, which was an unexpected surprise, but we couldn't put it down it was so good.  We got the mushroom fettucine as well as the chicken marsala, which both were great.  

We were glad to see all the dishes being made to order with really fresh ingredients.  Watching the food prep area is an experience I would suggest, should you be given the option.  It was like dinner and a show at the same time.
author: Molly R.

description:
I hate to do it but I must- the service here really needs a boost... We came in again for happy hour last night and had the same inattentive server. I believe he means well but it appears that he just moves too slow. 
When you do happy hour and are crunched for time to get in that last drink order before happy hour ends- you really want an attentive server so that you don't have to go running to him to place your last order. I know it sounds awful but we all do it- when you go to a happy hour you are watching the time to make sure you time your drinks just right, even if unconsciously...
author: Janell D.

description:
The task: find a place palatable for Republican, Midwestern relatives and their banking industry associates, near their hotel downtown.

The solution: Puccini & Pinetti, a place I'd always walked by with amusement, chuckling at the tourists within, but P&P turned out to make decent food and made the evening a breeze.

Because Midwesterners have no idea what going out for dinner is really like at 7pm on a Saturday night in San Francisco, they added two people to our party at the last minute, so my reservation for four was useless. But Puccini & Pinetti seated us immediately anyway with no issues. Major, major points for that. 

The restaurant's Italian-by-numbers and brightly-colored interior might seem about as authentic as Disneyland to San Franciscans, but it turned out to be wildly exotic to the Midwesterners. "What's pomodoro sauce," they asked the waiter. Seriously. God bless them. But they ordered two bottles of wine and gobbled down all their food, and they thought their crazy liberal nephew was a genius for taking them to such a great place. 

In all fairness, the calamari were pretty damn good, and my scallops with asparagus/prosciutto risotto was totally tasty. It probably gets made better at 20 places in North Beach for half the price, but that's not the point.

We all agreed the chocolate creme brulee was pretty bad, though.

So, San Franciscans, when sweatshirt-wearing relatives come out for conferences and want to go our to dinner and you don't want to bother with a cab and stuff, P&P is a great bet. Plus, now you can enjoy listening to them talk about wanting to emigrate.
author: Ben G.

description:
I am always at odds of where to take my mom for dinner.  She is so picky in a not picky at all way and once she finds a place, she only wants to go there.  This has been a point of contention on several occasions.  The two restaurants she picked for mother's day were Buca di Beppo and the Cheesecake Factory.  Out of the plethora of wonderful restaurants in the city she gets excited over a chain!

So I suggested P & P to her and "god be praised" she agreed.  We did a bottle of wine and several appies and it was good.  The stand out items though were the bean stew and the goey chocolate cake.  I would go back just to have those two items again.  

My best friend used to work here and I suggested this place because Mom possibly would eat there and two the staff has always been amazingly good spirited and friendly.  My best friend even was allowed to throw a fundraiser here where she raised money as a guest bartender for a friend who needed money for a surgery to save his life.  I was impressed with the staff and their support because of it. 

We met the owner that night and she was delightful and really personable.  She treated us to dessert on the house because she knew my best friend.  Great experience for mom's day as mom was tickled that we got just what she wanted and the extra attention.  I was just so happy to eat decent food as a good restaurant for once with her!
author: Cat A.

description: This restaurant is off the charts. Not only is the food amazing, the service is impeccable. Our server was Justin aka J man and he went out of his way to make our night special! 5 stars, no question about it. Ps highly recommend the salmon/ capellin
author: Carli L.

description: I order the steak salad which consisted of grilled flank steak, mushrooms, peppers, caramelized onions, gorgonzola cheese and balsamic dressing.  My wife orders the rustic Italian minestrone soup and the mussels with sliced fennel, fresh garlic, anisette and spinach served with grilled bread.  The food is good and my salad left me surprisingly satiated. This is reliable fare just nothing to write home about.
author: David E.

description:
The restaurant was packed when we arrived, but were offered bar seating and was seated promptly. One great thing about sitting at the bar is that you always get an entertaining cooking show!

We started the meal w/ complimentary foccacia bread(the dough was airy with hints of rosemary and olive oil, would have been better if it's served warm). Crispy Calamari & Vegetables($9.5, deep fried calamari, carrots, potatoes, broccolini, generously portioned served w/ spicy tomato aioli for dipping). Spaghetti & Meatballs($16, comes w/ three medium sized tender meat balls and abundance of bolognese sauce). Tomato Angel Hair Pasta($15, sauteed tomatoes, basil, garlic, & extra virgin olive oil, topped of w/ chewy fresh mozzarella balls).

Over all, the foods were good but a bit too oily for my taste, the menu selections were limited, and the service was prompt and friendly, watching all those chefs in action was the best part of this dinning experience!
author: Catherine W.

description:
My friends and I have decided to start sampling happy hour places. This was our first stop. I think we had high expectations and then were highly disappointed.  Both my friend and I were perusing through the photos on yelp and the menu deciding what we would order the night before. 

I honestly rushed out of work today because I couldn't contain my excitement for the delicious sounding food. The portions are small. The truffle parmesan fries were a dud. My other friend got the burger with regular fries. We couldn't really tell the difference. We also got the italian 3 cheeses with candied walnuts and apple slices - personally, I did not like this at all, but if you're a big cheese fan...it could be awesome. I would say it's because it has a VERY STRONG flavor that I'm not used to.  We also got a pizza, crispy calamari and breaded cheese raviolis. The raviolis were pretty yummy, but you only get 3 for $5.

Points for:
-really good calamari and garlic aioli dipping sauce. No rubbery taste there.

-$4 pizza.

-a table at a relatively quick speed. (This is probably because my friend went there early to beat the crowd.)

-good company and funny stories alongside cheap beer.

Points off for:
-not having the pasta nachos.

-disappointingly small portions.

I would give it 2.5 stars, but they don't have halves, so I just rounded up because I'm feeling generous.

Overall, it was okay, nothing spectacular. I'm not sure I would come back, maybe for dinner because of other yelper's raves of some of their dinner menu items. If it's near your office, it's worth a try...just don't have high hopes like me. 

High expectations for a happy hour place. Go figure.
author: Dolores L.

description:
If you're looking for food a bit out of the ordinary, and reasonably priced, this is a great place to go. The eggplant and spaghetti, mentioned in a previous review, is out of this world. And the vegetable plate-- pick four and they'll pile them high on a place for you, served steaming-- is highly recommended. Tony is my favorite server of all time. He knows what you're thinking and is always right there with what you need without hovering.

This restaurant is only one block away from the Powell St. BART station, so it's very convenient.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Amazing. Great central location to Union Square, great staff, good atmosphere and loud enough to bring your kids. We had delicious meatballs to start with, then amazing homemade ravioli's and pretty darn good short ribs. The kids enjoyed a good cheese pizza. I would go back.
author: Jen A.

description:
I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could.  Started with a glass of Cabernet and their bruschetta - which is more of a heap of stewed tomatoes, surrounding a scoop of goat cheese, seasoned with balsamic vinegar.  It was good - but a bit strong.  I did like how they adjusted the portions to my request since I didn't have to share the appetizer.

I had a pork chop with potatoes which were well prepared.  My pork was perfectly grilled - still a bit pink and very tender - not too tough at all.  Perhaps the onion seasoning was a bit excessive - but overall it was tasty and I ate it up.

This place seems pretty busy - but the aesthetic is a bit less intimate than Kuleto's (where I was on Sunday evening).  Food is pretty comparable.  I'd say try either one and you should get at least an above average experience and be pleased with your meal.
author: Jim S.

description:
It's a Murphy's Law of a restaurant. Seriously. Everything that could go wrong, did:

Wobbly table, chipped plates, no water despite asking, took several tries to get our glasses of wine delivered, pasta was stale and undercooked,1 dessert stale and the other flavorless, and the piece de resistance: the restroom had no running water!

AVOID, AVOID, AVOID
author: senga d.

description: I'm a self-titled Italian food snob, it is true. I did not find much resemblance between what I ate at this restaurant and what I consider to be Italian food. The arancini only looked like the yummy appetizer I have enjoyed in other locations. The service was poor to the point of danger: there were two different spinach salads on the menu. I specified which one I wanted but the other one arrived, the one that contained a cheese i was allergic to and would not have ordered. They changed it cheerfully, but the correct salad which arrived later was neither as large or as nicely put together as the first one that arrived. The wine by the glass was below par and the bar tender not very knowledgeable about the wine. After driving by this restaurant for years and always wanting to go, it was a disappointment. Great bar and sports bar atmosphere, but Italian restaurant, no.
author: Lua H.

description:
We had a quiet, earlier dinner before a show on a recent Sunday night.  Had the Wild Mushroom Raviloi and the primavera.  Both were very good.  Even the simple greens salad was exceptionally tasty.

The staff were awesome, all around.  Remembering my name from my reservation, and keeping tabs on us at just the right level.

We will definitely go back when in this part of town.
author: pat t.

description: Darling little place. Fig salad was delicious.  Service was great! Highly recommend stopping in.
author: Jill F.

description: This place is expensive for what you get... Guess they need to charge more to pay for the Union Square address. Food is just meh and service was just ok. There are many better restaurants in the area. My suggestion is to explore other places. I give it a 2.5 stars.
author: Pam A.

description: Excellent food and good service. I had a seasonal green salad and the risotto and both were delicious.
author: Monica W.

description:
Lest the owners of P&P start freaking out on me, 3 stars is a damn decent review from moi, ok?

It's Monday night, Union Square - where's the recession? This bistro was pretty busy. Could be their recession buster happy hour special, with great drinks 50% off. For me and my work colleague, it couldn't have been more right - not too fancy schmancy, straight up. And, yet, the several appetizers we ordered were still interesting. 

This is a place where you can order Chardonnay and not have you hang your head or mumble or make excuses about how the red tannins get to you. Furthermore, our waiter made a recommendation for Rodney Strong's Chard and it even used the word "buttery" without so much as a blush. And he was right. It was a delicious, buttery chard!

Comfy, unpretentious, but a little swanky cuz you're in Union Square. P&P - check it out!
author: maureen f.

description: The 3 hour delay that was our dinner service was definitely not worth the snobby attitudes from staff and mediocre Italian food....no matter how much free bread you can stuff your face with. This restaurant used to be really nice but is now just a hugely disappointing experience. You've lost a fan, Puccinni & Pinetti.
author: The D.

description: Took a chance - glad we did.  We were looking for a place close to 50 Mason Social Club before we went to see our son's improv show.  My husband, son and I ate here.  The waiter was very attentive and knowledgeable - brought us complimentary bruschetta - delicious - food was plentiful and tasty.  A little pricey - but we don't eat out that often and would come back here again.  We walked in at 7:00 on a Thursday night and got a table right away.  I would recommend reservations on Fri, Sat or Sun.
author: Jaci G.

description:
Shatangi's been twice and found it pretty good as far as food, drinks and service go. A little pricey.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description: I wandered into P&P looking for bite to eat and to watch some baseball.  I was pleasantly surprised.  I sat in the bar and the service was great.  I had the Arugula salad and it was huge but still fantastic.  The Capellini pasta was perfect and light - the fresh tomato sauce was more just crushed tomatos rather than a formal sauce.  I'm a big fan of P&P!
author: Nate A.

description: Food was alright, not worth the $,  but I didn't have the problem till after I left the restaurant when I looked at my credit card statement and realized I had a $80 charge and a $60 charge on it a few days later. I called the restaurant to talk to a manager and never got a call back! I had to cancel my credit card and file a fraudulent transaction against them. I will never go there again!
author: Steve S.

description: I will never eat here again $112.00 for a terrible dinner $20.00 for nasty spaghetti, lasagna tasted like garbage only thing that was edible was the pork chop, the short ribs were dried out and had no flavor It's an embarrassment to Italian cuisine I would of had a better meal @ the old spaghetti factory and gotten a free dessert! The bar was packed I guess the food might taste better if your drunk I think It would just make me puke!!!!!!!
author: Michelle P.

description:
This place was good.  Some solid italian food.  The wait was a bit long since we asked for wheelchair accessible seating - but a bit longer than I felt it should've been - so that's no good.  I had the lasagna and a salad on the side.  The veggie lasagna was nice and firm, not squishy (yuck).  Their bread was very flavorful.  And the salad was fresh.  I wouldn't jump back at the chance to come back (hence the 3 stars), but I would recommend it to others to try out.

The service, other than the waiting, was really good.
author: starrynight c.

description:
Always a good place to go if you're up for Italian food and want to rest your tired shopping feet in Downtown.  I fell in love with the butternut squash soup (it's a seasonal soup) - the best I had to date.  The wild mushroom ravioli and chicken marsala are good defaults.

The restaurant can be quite busy, so make sure to get reservations, especially on the weekends.  Even if you don't , the wait is not too long - I've never had to wait more than half an hour.
author: Julie C.

description:
To get ready for the half marathon, we had to find a place for some good pasta!!!  Since Puccini & Pinetti was right across from Hotel Fusion we decided to check it out.  

Of course their reservation is full and the next available table is at 8:45.   However, we were able to find two seats in the bar so we decided to eat there.

They had happy hour that ended at 6:00  on Saturday.
Truffle Parmesan Fries were to DIE for...  Pomegranate Sangria was good... They had a decent wine list... 
For dinner we ordered;
Soup Du Jour - Creamy roasted egg plant with spinach, Potato Gnocchi
in creamy basil sauce, and Frutti di Mare, seasonal seafood stew, tomato, basil, linguini, crostini  For dessert  we shared a glass of Justin port, and Warm Chocolate Cake.  Warm chocolate ganache , strawberry puree, vanilla gelato.  Our meal was AWESOME!!!   As for the service, it was great as well.. All the bartenders were funny and had corky sense of humor.  We were very happy and will go back again for sure...
author: Smarty Pants P.

description:
I used to love going to this place when they served "pasta nachos."  I would've given them 5 stars if they did.  

It was the only place to get them and they were awesome.  I read from another yelper that it's under new management.. maybe they brought them back.. will stop in to check if they do... then maybe I'll go back more often.   

BRING BACK THE PASTA NACHOS
author: B. D.

description:
Stopped in here for a late lunch - we were craving Italian, and I knew this place had been around several years and probably had to be decent.

Service was prompt and very friendly, nice laid back atmosphere, and only a few other guests there at 2:30ish.
They served complimentary foccacia, which was tasty but a little dense and dry. However, it came with a delicious olive/caper/sun-dried tomato tapenade that fixed everything.

For lunch we ordered bruschetta, an arugula salad, and the beet salad. Bruschetta was amazing, and I'll go back just for that. Soft buttery bread, a scoop of wonderful goat cheese, and a mix of stewed tomatoes, basil leaves, and balsamic reduction that was intensely flavorful - tangy, salty and sweet all at once, and absolutely perfect with the bread and cheese. Whoever invented this version of bruschetta is a genius.

The arugula salad was fantastic as well. Nicely crisp peppery-spicy baby greens, roasted corn, cherry heirloom tomatoes, chunks of avocado, onions, cucumbers, slivers of cheese, soft pesto croutons, and a lively sweet dressing. An ideal arugula salad!

By unfortunate contrast, the beet salad was pitiful. It was a pile of off-color, bad tasting lettuce leaves, some chunks of goat cheese, and surprisingly few pieces of beet, which were unpleasantly vinegary. We sent it back and just shared the arugula salad, which turned out to be plenty of food for both of us, anyway.

I definitely want to eat here again and try more dishes, hopefully they'll be on par with the bruschetta and arugula salad. Still giving them 4 stars for those two items and the great service.

They're priced kind of high, like everything else in the area, but they don't skimp on portions and the two of us got a delicious, filling lunch for around $25.
author: Kiri M.

description:
My husband I have been here multiple times for happy hour and always had a great time. Good food, good drinks... Even brought the family on. Mothers day and was great... HOWEVER we came in around 2pm on a Thursday with a big party and it was a nightmare!!! We waited forever for a table (even though was told it wouldn't be long) had a few apps in the bar and 1.5hrs later was seat. Then waited forever for our food, it was cold, wine was never served, a lunch in that place took 3.5 hours and not because we were having a great time :( we even had to serve our own water!!!

When brought to the attention of the manager, she could careless, and told me they were busy (which they were not, place was empty except for two other tables) 

Our waiter was very nice, apologetic and did everything he could to take care of us!!
author: alex r.

description: We walked in on New years eve on a whim and I was pleasently surprised , the pizza was good and everyone else enjoyed their meal.
author: Layla L.

description: It was okay... The food is kind of a little bit expensive for the quality of the food. The decor is nice and the service is alright. But again... the quality of the food is overprice.
author: Ronnel C.

description:
This is a favorite for my friends and mine to catch happy hour after a day at the art museums.  We have always managed to arrive about a half hour before the after work crowds show up, so our service has always been excellent despite the busyness of the bar.  It is close to our hotel so perfect for eating a late lunch or like we usually do, enjoy a table full of happy hour appetizers.  We always have the meat balls ,the formaggio, margherita pizza as well as Cesar salad and crostini and mozzarella. All wonderful.
I am not a house wine fan but theirs is delicious ,Chardonnay for my friends and a cab for myself  hard to believe they can sell it for $3.00
This great place wil always be a part of our trips to SF
author: Joan V.

description: Great food.  Especially love the olive/sundried tomato tapenade for the bread.  The Sea Bass was outstanding.  Everything was great except the Antipasto.  I did not like salami with all that fat.  After reading all the reviews here, regretted that I did not try the Bruschetta.  And by the way, why didn't we get it as a complimentary like the reviewers here?  I booked through Open Table too, like Rick.
author: Cindy B.

description:
Occasion: Romantic dinner for 2
We ordered: dungeness crab arancini (risotto balls), crispy calamari, creamy pesto & sundried tomato gnocchi, creamy chicken, raisen & walnut canneloni. Lattes instead of dessert.
Price: $75 for the two of us (including tax & tip)
What we thought: Calamari was probably the nicest I've ever had, especially texture-wise... not even a hint of rubbery texture... I thought it was fish the first bite I had! Arancini wasn't quite hot enough, but was still pretty good. Both appetizers were HUGE. Canneloni was very creamy, but yum. Gnocchi was a bit on the bland side, and not quite enough sd-tomato in it. Mains were quite modest portions compared to the appetizers, but I still only managed to eat about half of mine.
author: emma r.

description: Review for bar only: I need to be in the city most Monday evenings and I stop by here for happy hour almost every time. I enjoy a few items from the bar menu (parm fries and sausage being two) and the wine is quite decent for the price. Also, the bartenders are attentive and welcoming. Puccini & Pinetti is my go-to spot.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Solid Italian restaurant. I loved the Chicken Marsala and the sorbet trio was an excellent desert. The waiter seemed a bit distracted and didn't check back as often as expected but overall it was still a good experience.
author: A S.

description:
A little loud-even for a late Sunday evening.  
Friendly service-right on target.
Fantastic food.  The best meatball I've ever had, hubby's short rib was like Butta.  The olive/sun-dried tomato/caper tapenade they serve before dinner is super tasty--redeems the not-warm-at-all foccacia they serve it with.
A bit over-priced.
Hubby says he'll definitely be back.  I would only for happy hour perhaps.
author: Erin G.

description:
hi - just to be clear ... not a bad dining experience.  the service was great with the exception of the server.   the bartender replaced the martini that was made too dirty ... and the hostess moved us to a booth over table per our request.  the server basically did his job.  admittedly, we were very high maintenance this evening.  

however, the food is awful.  no taste and no flavor ... but lots of $$$.  we had the rigatoni, the risotto, and the papadelle pasta.   in my humble opinion, stay away.   there are too many other restaurants to try in sf.

atmosphere is ok, but fairly empty.  

overall, nothing bad happened ... it's just not worth paying $25 for pasta that you could have made better at home and for less than par ambiance and overall experience.  

sorry p & p.
author: Good U.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate their last night for the first time.

We were greeted by a super friendly host who happen to be standing in front of a basket FULL of my favorite little Italian gummy candies (I forget there name but I made sure to raid the hell out of the basket when I left!) We made it in time for happy hour appetizers. WE order a small plate of calamari and dates with roasted garlic.. Mmm Cheap and good. 

A Manhattan later and two vodka soda's deep our food arrived. 

Chicken Marsala for me and some CRAZY delicious Fetticinini dish for my main squeeze. BOTH TO DIE FOR-really. I'm border line vegetarian so the ONLY  thing left on my plate was a large piece of chicken but every last drip of my Marsala sauce and grilled asparagus were gone. 

Decor is cute, all Neopolitain colored scenes of San Francisco and black and white framed old photos surround a few  of the pillars that line the bar.

For an Italian woman myself, I approve. I will gladly be back.
author: Anne-Marie C.

description: When we arrived at the restaurant, we were seated right in front of the kitchen.
